title: world elephant day rescuing an elephant
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.We are protecting wildlife at risk from poachers due to the conservation funding crisis caused by Covid-19. Help is desperately needed to support wildlife rangers, local communities and law enforcement personnel to prevent wildlife crime. Donate to help Stop the Illegal Wildlife Trade&nbsphere.The Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.It was a particularly cold June morning in northern Kenya when rangers working in Loisaba Nature Conservancy first spotted a large male elephant limping near a watering hole. The rangers began monitoring the elephant, a large bull with enormous tusks, who was nicknamed Alan. Max Silvester, a Conservation Volunteer in Loisaba, said “the injury was likely the result of a botched poaching attempt. Alan had some of the biggest ivory I have seen.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesA wounded animal is liable to attack anything that comes close to it, and the elephant charged at the team who assembled to help him. “I was very afraid because he was huge,” said Loisaba’s Security Assistant Rita Orahle, who assisted KWS vet Dr Dominic Mijele.“He was trying to scare us by trumpeting because he knew he could not run away due to his injury”, said Dr Mijele. “I darted him and it became obvious that the wound was caused by a bullet which had entered the animal’s right foot, having first grazed the trunk.“After cleaning the injury and administering antibiotics I gave him an antidote and he walked off. If the elephant had been left untreated he would have been dead within a week.”All hunting is illegal in Kenya, a nation that has led the war against the plundering of wildlife, and ivory trafficking in particular. The Independent's Stop The Illegal Wildlife Trade campaign was launched to call for an international effort to clamp down on poaching and the illegal trade of wild animals.Funds raised will to pay for vital wildlife protection projects implemented by the campaign’s partner charity Space for Giants. This will work to help stop the poaching and illegal trafficking of animals.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailHowever the impact of Covid-19 means help is urgently needed to protect elephants against an increased threat of slaughter.In 2015 Space for Giants worked with international conservation organisation The Nature Conservancy to establish Loisaba as a conservation trust in perpetuity, protecting a critical habitat for a ersity of endangered species.Covering an area of 57,000 acres in the county of Laikipia, Loisaba has an increasing resident population of elephants, estimated at around 800, as well as an abundance of other fauna, including more than 260 bird species and 57 mammals, such as lions, leopards and cheetahs.Space for Giants supports wildlife monitoring, security and conservancy management in Loisaba, financed by The Nature Conservancy and other donors, including San Diego Zoo. The communities around Loisaba understand the value of wildlife, and the happy result is the conservancy is a zero poaching zone - a fact that even pachyderms themselves might understand. Silvester told The Independent “it’s likely that Alan the elephant was shot elsewhere, but the intelligence of this bull, in moving quickly to a place of safety Loisaba Conservancy, allowed the rangers and the vet team to assure his wound was treated quickly and successfully.“He continues to roam Laikipia as a testament to his forefathers, the huge tuskers before him.“Orahle adds “the rangers continued to monitor the bull, and he was last spotted in early August looking happy and not limping at all.”Alan was not the only animal to be rescued in Loisaba that day. The ranger team rushed off to treat a giraffe with a split hoof. In the midst of a raging global pandemic Loisaba’s wildlife operations continue to protect endangered species, preserving bioersity and supporting local communities in the process.The wildlife veterinary unit that saved the elephant is sponsored by Sheldrick Wildlife Trust, working in collaboration with KWS, to attend wildlife cases in Laikipia. title: labour sir keir starmer help government kids back school
story: Just take their position on Brexit, which has always been as clear as mud.In the coming days though, the electorate will finally get to see what they’re made of.If they stick to Labour’s promise to get kids back in school, they’ll earn the respect of Brits everywhere.If they stay silent while a Labour peer plots to conspire with teaching unions to deprive children of an education, they’ll be shown up as pathetic cowards.Of course we want children and teachers to stay healthy.But given the peak of infection was back in early spring, the robust safety measures schools have put in place for the autumn term look more than adequate to us.Teachers have a moral and civil duty to educate our children, especially when the harm that the enforced absence is having on young minds is becoming painfully clear. And most are itching to get back to work.Sir Keir must stop watching from the sidelines, be vocal, and help the Government get our kids back to school.He can start by seeing off this shameless wrecking bid.THE news that deaths are down on the five-year national average for the seventh week running is cause for real celebration.Butwe are to keep the good news coming, sick Brits MUST go out and use the NHS when they need it.Alarming figures released last week showed that for every three people who died of coronavirus during lockdown, another two died because they wouldn’t or couldn’t access proper treatment for other ailments.Unless Brits start dealing with their health concerns now, it’s possible that deaths caused by lockdown could end up eclipsing those caused by Covid-.The low fatality rate should also be a wake-up call for young and healthy employees still claiming that they don’t feel safe going back to work.Covid is waning, but the unemployment epidemic is just beginning.THE world is rightly raising a collective eyebrow at Vladimir Putin’s irresponsible claim that Russia has developed a working Covid vaccine.Russia’s leader has a habit of being economical with the truth, and his scientists have worked suspiciously quickly.The world is desperate for a jab to end the global misery, but Putin and his Kremlin cronies are stamping over all accepted scientic standards.This macho power play is nothing short of reckless.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: a levels pointless grades no one can trust
story: If I were them, I’d choose a highish grade. It looks good on the CV.I say “results” — of course, they are not results, as such. Instead, teachers have been tasked with deciding how well each student might have donerequired to sit an exam. These predictions are then weighted by the exam boards.As you might expect, teachers tend to overrate the abilities of their students. Not least because it makes THEM look good. In Scotland, they were over-generous to the tune of  per cent — and even more so in some “deprived” areas.The Scottish schoolkids were pretty hacked off to find their grades reduced by the boards, and moaned about it. So the Scottish government caved in and let them have their original grades. The ones that were overvalued.And so when little Jimmy proudly displays his long list of As and Bs to prospective employers — or, God help us, a university — people will just snigger.They know he can’t spell his own name or, like the rabbits in Watership Down, count past five. Nobody will take the results seriously after the Scottish government did its cowardly U-turn.Sadly for the youngsters, they will be pretty meaningless results. Which is a horrible thing to say after they’ve been studying for so long.South of the border we’re doing things a little better. Kids will be able to take the grade awarded to them. Or they can choose to use the result they got in their mocks — exams taken before Mr Covid arrived on the scene. Or they can take a special written exam in the autumn.That’s more sensible. But I suspect, even so, that employers and the universities will be a little wary of taking the results at face value. They will have their doubts.All of this has happened because we’re trying to be kind to the kids. And the reason we’re being kind is because these past six months we have let them down badly. The Government has let them down — and even more so, the teachers.Too many schools had no virtual classrooms at all during lockdown. The kids might have been sent a few worksheets. But time with their teachers was non-existent, even via Zoom.Too many teachers have been absolutely bone idle. Two-thirds of children have taken part in no virtual lessons whatsoever. Schools refused to make them — so the kids skived. And that’s in schools where there WERE regular virtual lessons.My own child, a girl of , completed five physics papers during lockdown. And being my daughter, sent them to the wrong email address. Nobody checked, nobody cared.The truth is our kids have had six months of doing nowt. Being nice to them now because we ignored their needs through spring and summer is all well and good. But it does not excuse the disgraceful behaviour of the teaching unions. Nor the failure of the Government to stand up to the unions.The result of all this will be a bigger ide than ever between poorer and richer kids. The middle classes are flocking to the private sector — where schools WILL be open and there’s always a full timetable of virtual work.For the rest — just the suspicion that they have been treated very badly indeed. By the people whose responsibility it was to look after them.It’s time Labour came clean about our teachers. Do they want the schools to reopen or not  And no more weasel words about keeping everybody safe. You cannot eliminate risk entirely, as Sir Keir Starmer well knows.We are now in a recession. Nothing will drag us out of it more quickly than the schools reopening, full-time, no s nor buts. Then the rest of us can get back to work.THE former boss of McDonald’s is in trouble for having exchanged nude pics with fellow workers.Brit Steve Easterbrook, pictured with Alesha Dixon at the London  Olympics, is also in trouble for having slept with a few colleagues.Now, those pics.I don’t knowSteve has a Whopper, a Quarter Pounder, a Big n’ Tasty – or just a chicken nugget. But nobody complained about them at the time. All of his relationships were consensual. And Steve was a orcee. What seems to me wrong is McDonald’s banning all of its staff from having relationships in-house.I WONDER how Prince Andrew has been coping during this heatwave If you remember, he explained to the BBC’s Emily Maitlis that he has an inability to sweat. Just can’t do it. He must be bursting, underneath his skin. Perhaps he will explode.Me, I’m sick of sweating. A three-minute walk to the local river ends up with me looking like I’ve just swam a mile in it.I’ve even started wearing shorts, which I hate. The noncey scout leader look – it’s all the rage.The BBC was worrying about this hot spell. Wonderedit was the result of global warming.Isn’t it something to do with that thing called “summer” I seem to remember it kind of happening before, you know I’m talking about the people who, in the middle of a global pandemic, travel abroad for their holidays. And are then surprised there are problems on account of the fact that we are in the middle of a global pandemic.Truth is, I have about as much sympathy as I do for people who travel to appalling war-torn countries for their hols then whine at the British Government to get them out.Would it hurt THAT much just to stay in the UK this summer WEDNESDAY was a pretty bad day for grouse.They have it circled in their diaries each year, in red. The “Glorious Twelfth”. This is when City boys and braying toffs take to the grouse moors and start blasting away at anything that moves. Especially grouse. Slow, heavy birds. Not very bright. Hard to miss them from eight yards with a -bore, evenyou’re a halfwit.It’s a bad day for the rest of us, too. And for our countryside. Grouse moors take up an astonishing eight per cent of our land. And yet they are kept solely for the grouse and the , or so numpties who try to shoot them every year.As a result, these moorlands are almost entirely devoid of wildle. Just barren deserts full of heather and nothing .And the gamekeepers burn the heather every spring – just when any songbirds might be nesting. The rest of their time is taken up shooting or trapping our most beautul and endangered birds of prey.Gamekeepers have almost wiped out our hen harriers, for example. Those moors should be teeming with le. Andthey were they’d be a much more attractive proposition for tourists – who would really bring money in to the local communities.Why do we preserve eight per cent of our land for the benefit of just . per cent of our population  Just so they can wear tweed for a day and pretend they’re Carlos The Jackal Probably end up glowing like one of those light sticks kids have on Bonfire Night. One expert reckoned that a side-effect was swelling up until you’re the size of the Kremlin.In the US, President Trump was suggesting swallowing disinfectant as a cure. If we do get an answer to this virus, I suspect it won’t come from either world leader.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: glimmer of hope in grim data recession
story: Not only is the UK formally in recession. It’s in the deepest recession in UK history, the deepest of any G economy, and the deepest since the invention of Gross Domestic Product. There’s a glimmer of hope buried in the grim data, though. In June, when the Government began to loosen lockdown restrictions, the economy grew an astonishing . per cent. That’s the biggest month-on-month jump since records began. It’s clear that we DO stand a chance of a relatively swt economic recovery - but onlyBrits start going about their pre-Covid lives sooner rather than later. And with hospital cases down  per cent since the peak of the coronavirus pandemic, the NHS is in no danger of being overwhelmed. Of course Covid isn’t over and we can’t be complacent. But Government scientists are attracted to long-term lockdowns because they’re trained to think about public health in the narrowest possible terms. The rest of us, though, understand that in the long run, mass poverty and unemployment kills just as surely as any disease.It’s time to get Britain working.OUR sympathies are with A-level students facing uncertainty today. Given the unprecedented situation has wreaked havoc with their exams, no solution is going to be perfect.And so we offer broad support to the Government and its “triple lock” strategy, which aims to give the vast majority of English and Welsh pupils the results they deserve.It makes much more sense than the indiscriminately clunky Scottish strategy — which saw thousands of kids miss out on good grades, until Nicola Sturgeon was forced to make a humiliating U-turn and bump grades up.We are concerned, though, about the long-term prospects of school leavers across the home nations. If Rishi Sunak keeps incentivising businesses to take on apprenticeships, the class of  stands a chance of gainful employment plugging Britain’s many skills gaps.Butthe Chancellor drops the ball, the future of British teenagers looks a lot less rosy: Evidence from previous crises indicates that the under-s will bear the brunt of the job and pay cuts when this recession gets into full swing.Come on, Rishi. Don’t let Generation Corona down.IT’S not unusual to be accosted by Christmas music while shopping in November.But the Surrey store which stacked its shelves with Xmas goods as we sweltered in a record-breaking run of C heat has jumped the gun slightly.Our sympathies are with you, Santa.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dan wootton two foreign holidays coronavirus proud
story: CORONA shaming in our unappealing “new normal” has become so common that it’s losing any effectiveness.Glares for not wearing your mask while standing outside, jabs for coming a touch too close lining up for lunch and now judgmental sneering at folk who decide to go on holiday — whisper it — overseas.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesWell I’m done with that nonsense. I am proud to “confess” that I have been on two foreign holidays in the past month, utilising legal air bridges, and I am far from ashamed.The myth in coronaphobic Britain is that overseas trips are for the elite, rich and powerful: If you dare get on a plane to low infection-rate locales such as Italy or Greeceyou’re not showing solidarity to the Covid cause and risk spreading the damned virus.That rhetoric hasn’t been helped by the Government’s feeble air bridge policy, which puts any country with a region experiencing a minor outbreak at risk of being added to the quarantine list.The reality is the total opposite. If you and me are shamed into staying home now, travel WILL soon be limited to the elite, rich and powerful.The democratisation of tourism has been one of the most pleasing developments of this new millennium, with the explosion of budget airlines causing price wars and a move towards all-inclusive package deals.Yet our ability to keep seeing the world is now in real peril.Airlines are on their knees. Hotels are closing at an alarming rate. Many popular European tourist destinations remain ghost towns.Goons in the Extinction Rebellion movement have already talked weak parties including Labour into backing the introduction of more travel taxes.All for a virus that, albeit nasty, killed just a fth of the number of people who died from run-of-the-mill flu and pneumonia in the final week of July in the UK.If you’re one of the many people currently tormented over whether to take the risk and book that break, I implore you to go for it.On a practical level, both my week-long trips to Europe were pure ecstasy, with responsible and reassuring safety measures that never came close to overshadowing the glorious experience of being overseas again, something unimaginable just a couple of months ago.Yes, the airport is a little more torturous than usual and you do have to keep the mask on at all times.When I arrived on the Greek Island of Mykonos last week, I was random Covid tested at immigration, causing a touch of nervousness while I waited -hours for the result.  And you’re not going to be able to dance or listen to loud music at night.But the benefits are endless. Your favourite tourist destinations are emptier than they’ve ever been during peak season, you’ll always get into your favourite restaurant, and the staff on British Airways have never been happier to see you on board.Most importantly,more of us choose to fly now, we will help keep affordable travel and tourism viable for years to come.I was one of just three people in total in a gym this week for a pre-booked, hour-long session.When we were booted out the moment our  minutes were up, the entire fitness centre was shut for a -minute deep clean.While we should, of course, encourage cleanliness, these types of self-imposed and over-the-top rules will make it impossible for most businesses to survive long-term.A healthy dose of common sense should be required, too.THE Prince of Woke emerged from his latest multi-million pound Calornian mansion this week to preach to the world, yet again, about racism.In an online conversation with Rashad Robinson, president of US civil rights group Colour Of Change, the usual clichés and judgy mumbo jumbo were out in full force.He spoke of “acting, rather than just saying”, going to “the root of the problem” and charity being “like bringing a bucket of water to a forest fire”.But what Harry didn’t talk about was his own notorious past of racist language and cultural insensitivities.After all, this was the Duke who was forced to undergo racial sensitivity training in the Army after using the P-word to refer to an Asian soldier.And this was the Duke who wore a Nazi unorm to a friend’s birthday party.If Harry wants to help spark real change and debate, it would be much more effective for him to stop the meaningless platitudes and talk publicly in some detail about his own journey.How did he realise that using the P-word as an adult is unacceptable in any circumstances How did he learn that larking about with a swastika around your arm as a member of the Royal Family is just plain wrong The Duke does have a valuable contribution to make about the need to stamp out everyday racism in society – one that will involve less pious preaching and more examination of his own notorious follies and foibles.LIKE Emily Maitlis, Naga Munchetty has become such a powerful BBC News presenter she believes the rules of the public service broadcaster no longer apply to her.First, the Breakfast presenter threw impartiality out the window to express a negative view about the US president Donald Trump.Now this week she has been caught pocketing cash to appear in corporate videos for the troubled car company Aston Martin.The Sun’s TV Editor Andy Halls revealed Naga didn’t follow protocol by seeking approval from her Beeb bosses and did not declare the fee she received either.That would be a sacking offence for most Beeb newsreaders.But Naga received the most minor slap on the wrist, with BBC bosses saying, “She has been reminded of the risk of conflict of interest when undergoing external engagements”.No wonder other BBC news presenters don’t want to follow the rules either.The corporation’s weak approach is asking for trouble.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or title: increase levelled off easing restrictions
story: Indoor theatre performances, casinos, bowling alleys and ice skating rinks will be able to throw their doors open again tomorrow after a relaxation of measures was paused last month. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe current rate of infections in the UK is . cases in every , people. The number of new cases has slowly climbed above , a day over the last week - but officials have said the overall rate is levelling off.The Office for National Statistics said today: There is evidence that the incidence rate for England has increased in the most recent weeks following a low point in June and appears to have now levelled off.Boris Johnson said today: “Most people in this country are following the rules and doing their bit to control the virus, but we must remain focused and we cannot be complacent. “At every stage I have said our plan to reopen society and the economy is conditional and that it relies on continued progress against the virus. “Today, we are able to announce some further changes which will allow more people toto work and the public to get back to more of the things they have missed. However, as I have always said, we will not hesitate to put on the brakesrequired, or to continue to implement local measures to help to control the spread of the virus.” Plans to reopen indoor theatre and music performances, casinos, bowling alleys and ice rinks were paused a day before they were scheduled to have restrictions relaxed on August . But they will now be able to open from tomorrow - and beauty salons will be able to offer close contact treatments such as eye threading and facials. Wedding receptions with sit-down meals will also be able to restart for up to  guests.The further easing of restrictions will not be extended to areas such as Manchester which have local lockdown rules in place - and indoor gatherings are banned. The Government has also announce they will be doing allowing a small number of people into some sporting events to test the safety of reopening them to spectators from tomorrow. Current plans would allow them to reopen to fans from October . Business events and conferences will also be allowed to restart from October infection rates stay under control. The Government has cracked down on people refusing to wearing face masks and ramped up fines - repeated offences can now escalate to penalties of up to £,. title: sellafield nuclear site evacuated explosive chemical
story: Bomb disposal experts cleared part of Sellafield nuclear plant in Cumbria after organic peroxide was found during a routine inspection yesterday.The plant was shut down and will remain closed until the chemical can be safely removed from the sites Magnox Reprocessing Plant.Bosses said the chemical - which is commonly used in plastics and rubber industries - is away from the nuclear operation.They stressed it poses a conventional safety issue rather than a nuclear safety risk.Sellafield Ltd said in a statement: During a routine inspection of chemical substances stored on the Sellafield site, a small amount of chemicalswere identied as requiring specialist disposal.This chemical is used for a iety of purposes across many industries. In line with established procedures, support has been requested from Explosive Ordinance Disposal .The EOD team is now in attendance at the Sellafield site and will dispose of the chemical safely.The company added: This chemical substance was stored in the sites Magnox Reprocessing Plant. The storage area is safely segregated from the nuclear operations of the plant and the risk has been identied as a conventional safety issue rather than a nuclear safety risk.As a precautionary measure, a controlled evacuation of the Magnox Reprocessing Plant was carried out yesterday in order to investigate the chemical and devise the appropriate course of action.The plant was non-operational at the time. The plant will remain non-operational while the chemical is disposed of.As ever, our priority remains the protection of our workforce, community and the environment.It comes after bomb disposal experts were called to the plant in  following a similar incident.Their report found the site had failed to identy the risks of out of date chemicals, the Daily Mail reports.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: amazon delivery driver wees outside house
story: Disgusted Sarah Merrix, , slammed the behaviour as unacceptable and shared the revolting footage online. In the clip, taken on Thursday, the driver is seen relieving himself against Sarahs garage before continuing to handle post.The video begins with the driver parked up on the street in Portsmouth.He jumps out and pops the boot to reveal a load of parcels bearing the Amazon logo.He then walks over to Sarahs garage, unzips his shorts and begins to urinate.The man looks around quickly before fastening his shorts and heads back to the car, treading in the puddle of pee as he goes.Without washing or sanitising his hands, he then picks up several boxes from his boot ready to deliver.A horried Sarah took to social media to complain to Amazon, saying: Can you please explain to me why your driver is taking a p*** against my garage Is this acceptable behaviour, I suggest you trace him and send him back to clean my garage. If he is not available then I suggest you send professional cleaners. Before I send this video to the police.Also as its been pointed out, as I was too angry at the start.e didnt wash his hands with water or even antibacterial wash, no gloves, and then handed packages to a customer that had no idea what he had done. Disgusting cretin.Others on Facebook were just as outraged.Alister Williams wrote: All those germs hes putting all over everyones packages! Definitely breaching health and safety.Natalie Reynolds added: Jesus especially in the current situation we cant even cough or sneeze let alone urinate on someone’s property! Gross.And Stephen Morgan said: That is disgusting.Sarah said the ordeal was made even worse by the fact she recently lost her partner, Dom Merrix, to coronavirus.Speaking today, customer service adviser Sarah said: This Covid- is very raw to us and I am trying to get the point over that his actions could harm someone.I lost my partner  weeks ago to this virus. I dont want sympathy, I just want to get the seriousness of hygiene out there.Im angry and upset. Its just disgusting my -year-old opens that garage andI hadnt had an alert of motion I wouldnt have known.She or I could have put our hands in it or anything, plus the lady he delivered to was unaware he had done this. I dont think they seem to understand the seriousness of this.She added: All their staff should be wearing masks and gloves when delivering. They should have some sort of device thatthey need to go to the toilet they can use it in their car away from public eyes, kids play out in my street.Id like a professional clean or maybe a new garage door as there is now a smell of urine during the heat.I think they should also apologise to the lady down the road and send her a bunch of flowers too.Amazon apologised, offered a professional clean and a hamper, and confirmed the self-employed driver has been sacked. A company spokesperson told The Sun Online: This does not reflect the high standards we have for our delivery partners. title: jeffrey epstein something on prince andrew documentary
story: In Surviving Jeffrey Epstein, accuser Lisa Phillips claims sex slaveVirginia Roberts was not the only woman the twisted tycoon dispatched to the under-fire royal.“Most of the girls didn’t speak about what happened with Prince Andrew, but I had one very good friend who confided in me about her experience with him,” she claims.“She told me that Jeffrey kind of instructed her to go into a room and have sex with Prince Andrew.A number of contributors to the four-part series - being screened on Letime -also claim Epstein would provide the woman to his associates before he wanted to have control over other powerful people.“He just mentioned that he needs to have something on people,” adds Phillips.Roberts told the documentary: There were times that he would send me on a commercial flight to go meet the people… saying, ‘I want you to take care of them and report back to me what they liked, what you did for them.Forensic psychiatrist Dr Barbara Ziv explained: “Once [Epstein] gets someone to accept to have sex with an underage kid, it gives him some power over the inidual when the inidual accepts.[Epstein] thought of these girls as commodities. He gave them out like he’d give out a good bottle of wine or a trip on his boat or a flight to somewhere…They were nothing more than objects to him.Numerous former associates of Epstein have also said that the rooms in his vast Manhattan townhouse, where Andrew is known to have stayed, were fitted with cameras.The cameras are said to have been intended to capture compromising footage of Epsteins guests.Describing the rumours, New York Times journalist Christopher Mason, a one-time friend of Maxwells, says: “The stories I kept on hearing were that in every guest bedroom in Jeffrey Epstein’s house, there were hidden cameras.“And that part of Jeffrey’s ability to manipulate was that he had this video of powerful men having sex with underage girls.And these recordings were held in a safe that Jeffrey was using as a power tool to manipulate wealthy guys to make them do whatever he wanted.”Shamed financier Epstein killed himself in a New York cell last August while awaiting trial on charges for the sex trafficking of minors.Andrew has long faced questions about his association with Epstein and alleged Epstein madam Ghislaine Maxwell, currently awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges.Maxwell strongly denies the allegations against her.Roberts has previously alleged that she was trafficked by Epstein over a two-year period after being introduced to him by Maxwell in the summer of .She says that, in that period, she was forced to have sex with the prince on three occasions - once in London, once in New York, and once on Epsteins private Caribbean island.The royal has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing regarding any accusations and has not been charged with any crimes.Repersentatives for the royal did not wish to comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prigozhin wagner calls russia putin
story: Moscow has denied links to Yevgeny Prigozhin, dubbed “Putins chef”, and his alleged security firm Wagner Group insisting the businessman provides catering services to the government.However, data published by investigative news outlet Bellingcat shows restaurateur Prigozhin was in regular contact with Russias top officials.He used his personal phone number to make the calls to elite members of Putins regime between  and , it has been reported.Wagner soldiers have fought in war zones such as Libya, Syria and the Central African Republic but authorities have strongly denied they take orders from the Kremlin.Strongman leader Putin, who once headed up the countrys spy agency the FSB, was previously pictured with Wagner troops at a government .Lieutenant colonel Dmitry Utkin, who is believed to have founded the group, was also in the photograph.According to Bellingcat, Prigozhin called and texted Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov  times in an eight month period,He also A lot of these problems will go awaystudents get to appeal.”Lib Dems called on Gavin Williamson to resign over the debacle.Someone even changed Mr Williamsons Wikipedia page to call him a clueless politician. It was changed to say: He is completely out of his depth in his current role and should resign with immediate effect. The changes were removed shortly afterwards, but people were piling in with edits criticising the Education Secretary throughout the afternoon. Education spokesperson Layla Moran said: “Gavin Williamson is an education secretary out of his depth and out of excuses.“He must take responsibility for his mistakes and step down with immediate effect. Our young people and our country cannot afford these blunders to continue into September ahead of a potential second wave.Several Tory MPs voiced their discontent about the exams system - in a sign of a possible growing rebellion for the Government.David Davis, former Brexit Secretary, said: Yesterdays results do not properly recognise... that students determined to go to their first choice university work hard and effectively to up their grade.Telford MP Lucy Allen tweeted: An algorithm that awards a ‘U’ to student that did not have the chance to turn up for an exam is fundamentally flawed.And Julian Sturdy, the MP for York Outer added: In my opinion, we shouldnt be downgrading grades or worrying about grade inflation this year as we are clearly living in unprecedented times. We need to fix this situation swtly before it has a permanent effect on the future of students in York and across the country.One MP told The Times: “What does it say about us when as a government pushing the levelling-up agenda we allow a system that favours private schools  I don’t think voters will think we are doing it deliberately — but in some ways being seen as incompetent is even worse.”Headteachers have warned they expect an even bigger fiasco next week when teens get their GCSEs.But Whitehall insists they are not budging, and said that grade inflation would have gone supersonic without moderation.Grades would have shot up by  per cent in a single yearteachers marks were not changed, exam bosses have said.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nicola sturgeon france mad dash
story: The Scottish First Minister and other leaders demanded the time be moved during crunch calls over looming new quarantine measures.It sparked  hours of hell for Brits stuck in France who now face a race around the clock to get back by am on Saturday.Its understood Downing Street wanted the quarantine cut off to be on Sunday, to give people more time tohome before self-isolating for two weeks.But Ms Sturgeon and Welsh First Minister Mark Drakeford joined forces to bring in the measures more quickly, Government sources claimed.Mr Shapps fuelled the chaos last night when he mistakenly announced the radical moves would be for people who come back from Sunday.What we know so far:At the daily briefing in Edinburgh today, Ms Sturgeon insisted it had been right to move fast.She said: Where we have a situation where we think a situation in a particular country has deteriorated we cannot hang around before we impose quarantine.There is a real imperative to act as quickly as possible.Despite causing havoc, the day of notice is more than travellers in Spain had - when the news of their quarantine broke with just a few hours notice.And residents in the North of England were given just over two hours warning ahead of their fresh local lockdown a fortnight ago.Around , Brits are holidaying in France at the moment, the Department for Transport estimates. And thousands are now desperately trying to get back to the UK before the new rules come into force tomorrow morning.Tickets to get home have been extremely hard to come by, with thousands joining online waits for the Eurostar booking system and prices hiked for rail, sea and air travel.BA flight prices rocketed from £ to £, and Eurotunnel Le Shuttle warned all shuttles are fully booked until tomorrow with no additional capacity being added.From the early hours of this morning winding queues built to board ferries at Calais for Dover - with passengers struggling to get last minute tickets. Brits are being told not to turn up at ports without tickets as they will likely be turned away.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said anyone who turns up trying to get a last minute seat home before the quarantine comes into force will almost certainly be disappointed.Mr Shapps told Sky News: Dont just turn up because you will almost certainly be disappointed and it will just create queues which no one wants to see.IT manager Lewis Kitson, , said: “This is just a complete shambles. It’s chaos. They’re making it up as they go along now.“They can’t justy this. It’s guess work. I’m not bothered about quarantineI’m too late. I’ve just come through France on a road trip. I’m trying to book to get home.“They’ll have to put me in prison before I comply with quarantine.“The whole thing is ridiculous. It’s still not enough time. I’m really trying to get a ferry booked. It’s a disgrace.”Are you stranded in France  Call The Sun Online newsdesk on   , WhatsApp us on    or email tips@the-sun And another ing Brit revealed she was forced to quit her job on a superyacht in the south of France over fears quarantine would make her miss her first few weeks at university.The -year-old stewardess, who arrived into London’s St Pancras International at am today, said: I dont think the quarantine is a good thing at all. I think it is so stupid. “There is nothing whatsoever stopping anyone visiting their friends and family when they have been travelling.”The Sun can reveal concerned medics intervened to warn the PM that France’s numbers were starting to spiral out of control.France recorded , new Covid- cases yesterday — a record outside of lockdown - and the infection rate over  days rose to . per ,.British tourists in France are being charged hundreds of pounds tohome before quarantine restrictions are imposed.British Airways hiked fares up to nine times for passengers ing from the south of France.The final seats on its afternoon and evening flights from Nice to London were costing € and € – compared to E for passengers flying next Monday, a kayak search showed.DFDS Seaways doubled fares for ferry passengers sailing from Calais to Dover yesterday, with two passengers and one car costing £, compared to the £ next week, a directferries search showed.PO ferries had availability last evening - but prices were at least £ a car, rather than £ on normal days. The lowest priced Eurostar tickets available this morning were £.Travellers willing to pay these inflated fares could still miss out due to many services already being fully bookedThe PM risks a row with France’s president Emmanuel Macron, who was on holiday yesterday in the South of France.Frances secretary of state for European affairs said the UK decision would lead to reciprocal measures across the Channel.Clement Beaune tweeted: A British decision which we regret and which will lead to reciprocal measures, all in hoping for afor normal as soon as possible.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: top secret parliament plans greggs
story: Bakers working in the Westminster branch were shocked to find the detailed plans and immediately handed it over to police on Wednesday.The Sun understands the documents - which included detailed maps of the Palace of Westminster - were left by the silly sausage at the bakery inside the nearby Tube station.They were picked up by a member of staff who flicked through the pages decided to hand them in to police.A pal of the staff member said: “As soon as they realised what it was they handed it in – luckily no member of the public saw what was inside.”It’s understood the documents included plans of the Houses of Parliament – which are restricted for security reasons.Contractors were dispatched to collect the plans from the branch on Thursday morning – only to be told that they were in the hands of local coppers.The Sun understands they were later ed to the right person.Commons officials said that they were investigating the security breach.A House of Commons spokesperson said: Documents were left by a contractor outside of the parliamentary estate but have now been ed.“The House of Commons takes the matter seriously and is currently investigating this incident.”The Houses of Parliament are undergoing restoration and renovation which includes upgrades to security facilities.The building has been a top target for terrorists for decades.In  Islamic fanatic Khalid Masood murdered PC Keith Palmer at the gates and four pedestrians nearby after he rammed his car along Westminster Bridge.Greggs declined to comment when approached by The Sun.The Met Police said: On  August, a police officer at the Palace of Westminster took receipt of documents found by a member of public. title: greater manchester lockdown coronavirus case rate
story: Current vital rules on gatherings in the North West will remain in place to tackle the spread of the disease, the Department of Health and Social Care said today.Other areas to be affected by todays announcement include West Yorkshire, East Lancashire and Leicester.Casinos, skating rinks, bowling alleys, exhibition halls, conference centres and indoor play areas will not be permitted to open in these areas.The latest data also shows a continued rise in cases in Oldham and Pendle while numbers remain high in Blackburn with Darwen.Government officials will now work with local leaders in these areas by setting up a enhanced incident team to tackle the rate of infection.Residents will still not able to meet people they do not live with inside a private home or garden – unless they have formed a support bubble.Locals will not be allowed to socialise with other people in pubs, restaurants, cafes, shops or places of worship.People can, however, meet others in groups up to six iniduals – or two households – in outdoor public places.But nail bars, spas, beauty salons, pools and indoor gyms will remained closed in Leicester, Blackburn and Bradford.Vulnerable people will still need to shield in Blackburn with Darwen and Leicester.Meanwhile, Newark and Sherwood in Nottinghamshire were added as areas of concern following a recent spike in coronavirus cases.Today, the Health Secretary said the strict rules - introduced two weeks ago - must remain in place to help protect local residents. Edward Argar, Minister for Health, said: I’d like to thank everyone in Greater Manchester, West Yorkshire, East Lancashire and Leicester for their continued patience in following these vital rules put in place to tackle the spread of the disease – I know it hasn’t been easy.“We will review the measures again next week as part of our ongoing surveillance and monitoring of the latest data.“It is essential we all remain vigilant, and I urge everyone in these areas to continue to follow the rules.Wash your hands regularly, follow social distancing, get yourself a free test as soon as you get any symptoms, and isolateNHS Test and Trace tells you to.”A spokesman for Greater Manchester Combined Authority said: The Mayor of Greater Manchester and leaders once again agreed on Wednesday that increased restrictions should continue across the city-region for another week.The situation in Greater Manchester remains challenging. It is clear that while the current restrictions appear to be having a positive effect in some places, we urgently need to bring the number of cases down in several boroughs.Everyone in Greater Manchester must do all they can to reduce the number of cases. That means iniduals, pubs, restaurants and supermarkets all taking this seriously and following all the regulations.We will continue to work as one Greater Manchester system with a particular focus on providing support to Oldham as they strengthen further their intensive test and trace operation.It comes after a surge in coronavirus cases among people in their s and s in Oldham.Leicester saw the first local lockdown on June . At that point, the infection rate in the East Midlands city was  cases per , people.In Oldham, the current rate is . per , people.This week, locals were told to “act now” to avoid Leicester-style restrictions just days after cops received  calls about people breaking rules to host parties over the weekend.Oldham Council had previously warned: “You need to act NOW. If everyone makes these small changes we can avoid a second lockdown - but there is no time to lose.“The best way to stop the spread of the virus is to limit those who you have contact with – spend time with those in your household and work from home where possible. DO NOT have visitors to your home or garden.”Councillor Arooj Shah, Cabinet member for coronavirus recovery, said the borough was in a really “serious” situation.She said Greater Manchester Police received a hundred calls over the weekend with reports of locals breaking rules to host parties and BBQs in Oldham.Greater Manchester Police said they received , reports of people flouting newly-imposed restrictions across the whole county last weekend.Tougher lockdown restrictions were reintroduced in Greater Manchester and other parts of northern England on July , following an upsurge in Covid- cases.Anyone found flouting the rules could be fined £ up to a maximum of £, for repeat offences.The restrictions must be reviewed every fortnight.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailI’m guessing that during the Black Death the story on everyone’s lips was Edward III’s grandson throwing a strop over the crippling pain of being born stinking rich. And that a Nigel Farage figure sent sketches back from Kent beaches of Flemish refugees fleeing lowland flooding, which were pinned on billboards under slogans telling of “The REAL Killer Plague.” Because whenever this country is in crisis, royals and foreigners are the go-to smokescreens. In this catastrophic year, Prince Andrew took our mind off things. And now there’s a much-hyped book out, clearly approved by Prince Harry, in which he whines from a Calornian mansion, with nil self-awareness, about the terrible hand le has dealt him.If a second Covid wave hits expect Anne or Edward to come out.  Meanwhile – as Farage desperately seeks relevance by calling asylum-seekers in dinghies heading here from war-torn countries an “invasion”, and the equally desperate Priti Patel proposes military action to outflank him – the truth about the UK housing a mere  % of the world’s refugees is lost. Just as the Queen Mum did East End photo-ops during the Blitz and the cowardly French were blamed for Hitler having Dover in his sights, it’s standard British distraction tactics from a government losing its grip. The dference being that in the past they got away with it. But no amount of royal drama or xenophobia will help Boris Johnson and his motley crew, because it is the most incompetent government in living memory. Each day throws up fresh evidence of its pitul inadequacy. My new favourite is that not only did they screw up every aspect of the Covid fight, resulting in the worst death rate in Europe, they couldn’t correctly add up the corpses. They were more than , out.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIndoor theatre, music and comedy performances can restart tomorrow, along with a host of beauty treatments after fresh coronavirus lockdown curbs were lted. Facial threading and waxings resume in England almost five months after they were banned in a bid to curb the spread of Covid-. Snooker fansto the World Championship at The Crucible, Sheffield, to watch the final. The moves were announced alongside plans to relax rules on businesses including bowling alleys, skating rinks and casinos. Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said: The nationaposs hard work to keep the virus under control means we can now make further careful progress on recovery with allowing audiences back for indoor performances, fans back at sports events and the reopening of more Covid- secure leisure businesses. We must all continue to stay alert but todayaposs welcome news means these organisations can finally get going safely, and we can enjoy more of the things we love as a nation. I have no doubt that they will work incredibly hard to keep their fans, patrons and customers safe. Hereaposs what you can - and canapost - do from tomorrow as coronavirus lockdown rules are eased. Holdwedding receptions  Wedding ceremonies have been allowed since  July, but only for a maximum of  people - and that includes the photographer. But until this weekend, the happy couple havenapost been allowed to celebrate their union in a traditional knees-up with friends and family. Rules had been set to change from August  in England to allow small, socially-distanced receptions of up to  people.But the move was one of those postponed for at least two weeks by  Boris Johnson.Receptions can now take place of up to  people in the form of a sit-down meal. Live entertainment venues will be allowed to reopen for performances for the first time in months - but thereaposs still a few catches. The maximum capacity of some venues will have to be reduced to ensure social distancing rules can be observed. And theyaposll have to deep clean regularly - including between performancesthereaposs more than one a day. The guidance says people should be seated, not standing - and recommends using booths, barriers and screens between performers and audience where possible. It also says venues with balconies should keep the first m worth of seats empty, so anyone coughing and spluttering in the cheap seats doesnapost infect the entire theatre. The biggest issue, particularly for live music performances, is going to be the ban on singing. Thataposs right, venues are asked to ensure audiences donapost need to unduly raise their voices to each other and discourage singing along to music or cheering, refraining from playing music or broadcasts that encourage shouting. The actorsapos union Equity said: “While we welcome this news, the majority of live performance can’t reopen with socially distanced audiences. “Our members are still out of work and in urgent need of income support.” Have brow and facial treatments  Salons were banned from restarting close-contact beauty treatments such as eyebrow waxing and facials with just a dayaposs notice, leaving customers disappointed. That is despite salons having opened from July . The dference is because thereaposs more risk of Covid-youaposre face-to-face with someone. From Saturday, these treatments can resume, including brows, eyelash treatments, make up applications and botox. New rules mean hairdressers and salon staff will have to wear surgical masks as well as clear visors, following a change in the scientic advice. This also applies to workers who visit people at home, such as massage therapists.  About  fans will be allowed into Sheffieldaposs Crucible Theatre to watch the World Championship Snooker final which begins on Saturday. The Championship became the first indoor live sports event in England to have crowds since lockdown, allowing some supporters in for the three sessions on July .However, they were kicked out the next day when a spike in coronavirus cases led the Government to halt its gradual lockdown relaxations.World Snooker said: “We are delighted to announce that a reduced crowd will be welcomed to all sessions of the final of the World Championship on Saturday and Sunday.” The snooker was among pilot matches where fans were admitted to test the safeof spectators at sports events. Ministers hope to allow a wider , with social distancing rules in force, from October. But getting back to normal with cheering supporters packed into stadiums is a long way off. Kids canto soft play centres - but not ball pits  Soft play centres will be allowed to re-open from this weekend. But theyaposll have to comply with a strict new set of rules. They include having hand sanitiser stations, one-way systems, reduced capacity, online booking, increased cleaning and antibacterial fogging. Visitors over the age of  will have to wear face coverings - and children must stay socially distanced and be supervised at all times. And crucially, the ball pit is out. Loose play items like the balls in ball pits will have to be removed because theyaposre hard to clean.  Punters can stick or twist at casino blackjack tables, claim a strike at ten-pin bowling alleys and glide on skates around ice rinks. The venues had been due to reopen two weeks ago but the lting of restrictions was axed at the last minute as infections crept up. British Ice Skating tweeted today: “Ice Rinks in England can open from tomorrow. “Yes! Letaposs get our athletes #backontheice. Thank you to everyone for their support.” Hollywood Bowl said: “Following the latest directive from the UK Government we are pleased to announce the reopening of our English bowling centres on Saturday th August. “Ten pin bowling is great all round fun whether you’re with family, friends or work colleagues. “With state-of-the-art bowling alleys, delicious food and drink and awesome arcades, we promise to keep everyone entertained.” ...and which parts of the country will remain more restricted for now  The latest lockdown relaxations do not apply in “specic areas where local restrictions are in place”. They include parts of Greater Manchester, Lancashire and West Yorkshire. And a small section of businesses across the country must still remain closed, despite this weekendaposs fresh easing of curbs.

story: NewsHairdressers and barbers ordered to wear surgical masks from today in huge U-turnFrom today anyone working in close contact services - which also include nail bars, beauty salons and massage and tattoo parlours - must wear a full-blown disposable type  mask to stop the spread of coronavirusShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  AUG NewsHairdressers and barbers in England have been ordered to wear full surgical masks" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Hairdressers and barbers in England have been ordered to wear full surgical masks to prevent coronavirus in a massive government U-turn.In a major change, anyone working in close contact services - which also includes nail and beauty salons - must wear a disposable aposType apos mask as well as a face visor from today.It comes as beauty salons are finally given the green light to resume high-risk services like eyebrows and facials from tomorrow. Boris Johnson finally introduced the rule more than three weeks after his experts said wearing a clear plastic visor wasnapost enough to stop Covid-.The only compulsory thing hairdressers have had to wear since they reopened on July  has been a face visor. A covering hasnapost ever been needed over their nose and mouth - despite becoming compulsory in nearly all indoor public spaces and on public transport.In a meeting on July , a sub-group of the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesruled visors alone are unlikely to be an effective control for aerosol transmission.SAGE added: We recommend that guidance for UK hairdressers and barbers should be strengthened to include wearing of face coverings. Yet the government dawdled over the findings for weeks, leading experts to speak out in protest. Now the guidance has finally been updated - and goes even further than what SAGE said on July . Instead of wearing a face covering, which can include a scarf or piece of cloth, anyone working in close contact services must now wear a full type  surgical mask. This includes hairdressers and barbers, as well as nail and beauty salons, tattoo, tanning and massage parlours, and dress fitters and tailors. Each mask must be worn only once and then discarded safely, ideally into a non-touch and self-closing bin.  New guidance adds: A Type II face mask should be worn with the visor. Type II face masks are not PPE but will provide a physical barrier to minimise contamination of the mouth and nose when used correctly. Ensure you are hydrated before putting a mask on. Face masks must also not be touched once on the face, and must be changedthey become moist or damaged, or dficult to breathe through. Downing Street said the move was taking into account new evidence provided by SAGE and consultation with industry. A statement added: This will help protect the customer and staff from respiratory droplets caused by sneezing, coughing, or speaking.  The original guidance to hairdressers, when they opened on July , said wearing a face covering may only be marginally beneficial, and the evidence it would protect customers is weak and the effect is likely to be small. Those phrases were removed on July , the day after the expertsapos meeting, and replaced with the words: There is growing evidence that wearing a face covering in an enclosed space helps protect iniduals and those around them from COVID-. However, face coverings are not an alternative for employees who wear a visor in close contact services. The guidance has now been updated yet again. The scientists made their recommendation after a US study found two COVID- infected hairdressers, who wore face coverings, did not pass on the disease to  clients.

Shopper Eve Whitty was left fuming with Asdaaposs response to her complaints regarding face masks in her local store. She said she couldnapost believe how many people werenapost wearing masks at the supermarket and went to raise her concerns with a member of staff. Eve also approached a group of men who she described as being in their twenties to ask why they were not wearing face masks and the following day she emailed a complaint to Asda, reports the Liverpool Echo. Eve has said she just wanted to highlight her concerns and was frustrated with Asdaaposs response that they are encouraging customers to wear a face covering. Asda said they are doing all they can to remind customers to follow the rules but ultimately it is up to police to enforce them. Eve visited the Huyton store on July  for one of the first times in months after she had been shopping online for herself and for her elderly relatives. She said: I said to a member of staff excuse me could I smoke in the store and she said you canapost do that in the store. One shopper allegedly said they had breathing dficulties, so Eve asked why their friends werenapost wearing them, before deciding to walk away. Guidelines say that people working in shops do not have to wear a face covering, but that customers should do so.

The UK government announced late last night that all travellers ing from France must now self isolate for  days from am Saturday. The Foreign Office also advised against all non-essential travel to France It sparked a mad rush to get back to the UK before tomorrow with big queues forming at the ferry port this morning as Brits tried to rush home. But savvy Julia Burnett, , and husband Craig, , had already cut short their camping holiday fearing the worst and were just  miles from Calais when the announcement was made. They drove yesterday for an incredible  hours from the South of France to Calais with their three children Rory, seven, Isabella, five and Finley, one.  They were due to come back next Wednesday but yesterday decided to set off from Biarritz, after reading rumours about a potential quarantine. The family, from Taunton in Somerset, managed to book onto a ferry less than an hour before the government announcement. When they were  miles from Calais they discovered their gamble had paid off when they saw news of the rule change. They were in the queue for the ferry crossing feeling “tired but relieved” this morning.  Julia said: “We’d been trying to book onto the Channel tunnel but we eventually booked on the ferry instead. “Then I checked back on the tunnel website straight after the announcement and I was ,th in the queue - it was crazy. “Quarantine would have really affected Craig’s work as he runs a dental services business and can’t do it from home.” The Burnett family were among half a million Brits said to be on holiday in France, with around , expected toto the UK before the summer holidays end.  Lucky Brits who were already due totoday or who managed to get a last minute booking arrived back in Londonaposs St Pancras station this morning. But many others scrambling to get home face paying hundreds of pounds and blasted the government’s decision. I’ve just come through France on a road trip. “They’ll have to put me in prison before I comply with quarantine. “The whole thing is ridiculous. It’s still not enough time. I’m really trying to get a ferry booked.” Michael Smallwood, , booked eight days’ camping in Calais with four pals. He was due to travel back on Monday but was today frantically trying to transfer his tickets after his we this morning called him from their home in New Ash Green, Kent, to tell him of the new rules.  Michael, who owns a cleaning business, said: “I’ve got lots of work planned in the next two weeks and soI don’t get back today, this could severely affect me financially. “It was announced late at night and I wish we had been given more time to get out. “PO’s response has been pretty disappointing so far. I haven’t been able to get through on the phone and I’m struggling to change our tickets.” British businessman Charlie Varley – who owns holiday homes in northern France - launched a scathing attack on Boris Johnsonaposs decision to impose quarantine. He said: “Itaposs a bloody nightmare. “Weaposve been hit all season because of the Brit government’s indecisive bulls**t.  “We have already had several cancellations we have had to refund earlier in the season and here we go again. “Ourselves and countless other gîteowners have lost a large part of our customer base. “And then the insurance companies refuse to pay out those customers who took out insurance because the British government just gave them a get out clause. “If the government imposed a quarantine, most people’s holiday insurance is null and void because technically they can still take the holiday. story: NewsCoronavirus surging in Yorkshire town where parts have higher rate than LeicesterAreas around market town of Halax in Calderdale are experiencing the fastest rise in infection rates across the region, according to its Public Director of Health, Debs HarkinsShareCommentsByDanielle Hoe:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsShoppers wear face masks as they walk through central Halax " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A Yorkshire town on lockdown reportedly now has a higher infection rate than Leicester - the first region to be placed back into stricter coronavirus measures.The borough of Calderdale is experiencing the fastest rise in infection rates across Yorkshire, according to its Public Director of Health, Debs Harkins. Areas around the market town of Halax now have infection rates higher than key hotspots such as Leicester, Blackburn and Darwen and Luton, she said. Government data shows the ward of Pellon East has seen a stark rise in cases, with  recorded between August  and . Pellon West and Highroad Well had  cases of coronavirus recorded across the same week. Debs Harkins has now appealed to the people of Calderdale to in a desperate bid to get help from residents to bring the rate back down again.Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog hereYorkshire, along with other major northern hubs such as Manchester and Leeds were placed back on lockdown meaning two households were no longer allowed to meet. The rules means families and friends could only socialise with those who they lived with or one other person living alone who had already formed a bubble with another houehold. The rules applied to both indoor and outdoor socialising.In her statement, Debs Harkins said it is clear that too many restrictions were lted too quickly and said she cannot stress how serious the situation is, reports Yorkshire Live. She said: The first of August was four months to the day since I started working in Calderdale. I began my work here at the beginning of April, a couple of weeks into the national lockdown. I marked my four-month anniversary with the introduction of local restrictions, brought in because the borough has one of the highest COVID- infection rates in the country. I have to say, these four months have been some of the hardest times in my  years working in public health. Just to give you some perspective, the only time that compares to this for me was the  months when I worked from a hospital isolation room as I underwent treatment for an aggressive form of Leukaemia, which I only had a % chance of recovering from.  Being the voice of doom doesn’t come naturally to me. I try to find the positives in every situation, even being treated with a le-threatening illness! But I’m sorry to say that I’m writing this today to stress how serious the situation in Calderdale is, and to ask for your help to tackle COVID-. I have been out and about in the borough, talking and listening to people in our communities, and I have heard from many people how shocked they are that COVID- is still here with us. I heard that people made enormous sacrices to keep infection rates low, and when the restrictions were lted in June, they believed that things would start toto normal and we could all start to enjoy the things we used to take for granted. People in high incidence areas told me they feel stigmatised and blamed for the situation we now find ourselves in. When we look at the trends in confirmed cases in Calderdale, it’s clear that too many restrictions were lted too quickly.  In parts of Halax particularly, the infection rates are among the very highest in the country. The situation can change rapidly, and at the time I’m writing this, there are no areas in Leicester, Blackburn with Darwen or Luton, where the infection rates are higher than those we can see in some parts of Halax. Infection rates in Calderdale are currently increasing faster than in any other borough in the Yorkshire and Humber region. She continued: I’m asking for your help today to bring the infection rate down. This is important to us all for many reasons. Geoff Cunlfeaposs three bed semi-detached house has a leaking roof, damp floors, peeling wallpaper, collapsed ceilings and black mould in every single room after he was preyed on by callous cold callers who offered to fit new insulation into his roof. The widowed pensioner handed over a total of £. to Eco Energy Advice Limited four years ago but only discovered the shoddy workmanship early this year when huge amounts of rainwater - which had been collecting in the loft - begin to seep into the house. A closer inspection revealed the work wasnapost completed properly meaning over time almost all of the tiles on the roof have lted. Now every time it rains Geoff is faced with more water seeping into the house causing ceilings to collapse and leaving every room damp and covered in black mould. Geoff, who has lived in the house in St Albans, Herts, for  years, was initially forced to sleep downstairs in a chair before kind neighbours used tarpaulin to temporarily make his bedroom safe again. He has also had numerous falls due to the damp, slippery floors, one of which left him needing hospital treatment. Geoff told : Iaposve lived in this house since  and have a lot of fond memories here. My we passed away in  and my son is retired now but it was a family home and we have always worked hard to look after it. When I noticed the damp coming through I borrowed a pasting table from a neighbour and was going to try and clean it up and wallpaper it myself but then it got worse and worse. A builder also advised not to touch it myself as the mould spores could be bad for my health. I have tried going through my insurance, and every other option available but Iaposm getting no help. I donapost want to live like this anymore, itaposs quite upsetting really.  The boss of Eco Energy Advice Limited, Adam Craig Roberts, was jailed for three years in June last year after a prosecution by Trading Standards. He pleaded guilty to fraudulently misleading people - often the elderly - and encouraging them to buy home insulation all to fund his own extravagant lestyle. In a bid to help repair Geoffaposs roof and bring his home back to its former glory, his neighbour, Barbara Meszaros, has set up a Go Fund Me Page to cover the cost of the damage - which builders estimate to be up to £,. Barbara said: Itaposs honestly heartbreaking. The whole house is damp and mouldy and he is living in extremely unsafe and unhealthy conditions.  All the tiles on his roof are lted which means more water seeps in every time it rains and as we live in the UK thataposs very often. This has already resulted in two dangerous accidents. He fell down the stairs due to the damp on the floor and parts of the ceiling caving in. There is not a single room in his home that is not affected by water damage and black mould including his own bedroom, which resulted in him having to sleep in a chair downstairs. We have managed to put some tarpaulin up for now to get him back into his bed but who knows how long that will last and it is continuing to get worse day by day.He has been so upset about this and itaposs heartbreaking to see. No one, especially no one of his age, should be living like this. He has always done his best to look after the house and itaposs such a shame itaposs come to this. He is the last person to ask for charity but we have tried other avenues and nothing has worked.

Ella Rose, , has spina bida and hydrocephalus and is paralysed from the chest down. The youngsteraposs father Jack Rose said she was pounced on after she got out her phone to call her personal assistant outside the supermarket in West Street, Sheffield. Mr Rose: Ella has only just been allowed to go out again and she went to town with her PA, who had gone in to the shop. Ella had got her phone out to call her from outside and ask her to buy peanut butter or something and an opportunist pounced, wrestled the phone from her and legged it.Luckily, Ella was not hurt in the mugging but Mr Rose said that she was quite shaken as nothing like this has ever happened to her before, reports Yorkshire Live. Itaposs the first kind of confrontation or any physical stress that sheaposs had as everyone is normally so nice and supportive, Mr Rose said. He added: I legged it to West Street when I heard and she was really shaken, itaposs quite sad. But we encouraged her to go back out because we donapost want her confidence to be knocked. But Mr Rose said that it was horrible for him as a father, knowing that he was not able to stop the attack from happening. Itaposs that defenceless feeling. Sheaposs a young  and me and my we have always done everything for her or with her and we trust that the world will treat her well, so itaposs that feeling of helplessness, he said. Mr Rose and his we were shocked to find out that there is no CCTV outside the Tesco on West Street so they cannot even find the person responsible. However, Mr Roseaposs sadness has even extended to the attacker himself. He said: Itaposs sad that someone has made those choices, no body dreams of growing up and snatching phones from disabled girls so I feel sorry for him too.

Her first video quickly gained , views and she went on to build up a following of more than , by frequently posting dance tutorials, comedy videos and beauty tutorials. I felt a bit guilty my videos were being pushed in front of other people working really hard, admitted Milana, who arranges the events for her family-run restaurant Il Padrino. She then took a break from the app, owned by ByteDance, a Beijing-based Internet technology company, before getting back in the swing of things and quickly gained another , followers. However she first noticed something was amiss when she posted a clip about a friend going into coronavirus lockdown in China - which she says got deleted.Maybe because TikTok is owned by a company in China then maybe they didnapost like it. But then it got deleted which was really crazy, she said. Milana then went on to post a clip bravely opening up about the birthmark at the top of her thigh while dressed in shorts and a jumper.
