story: In a move described by union officials as a ldquoworrying indication for the future, talks with a number of staff are being held.It is understood that three of the five ground staff who look after the course are being axed, leaving just two and the head groundsman.Racecourse manager Bill Farnsworth confirmed that redundancy talks were being held and pointed to the devastating impact of Covid- on the industry and Musselburghrsquos operations.However, GMB Scotland, which oversaw negotiations with East Lothian Council and Chester when the local authority brought them in to operate the racecourse, said it believed more options should have been considered.And it questioned how the award-winning course could keep up standardsthe workers involved were reduced so drastically.Benny Rankin, GMB Scotland organiser, said: ldquoWe are doing all we can to assist our members affected by these redundancies but there is no denying itrsquos a worrying indication for the future of this historic racecourse.ldquoWe believe that Chester havenrsquot explored all possible options to protect the employment of the existing workforce, including the use of the Government furlough scheme until its deadline, and this looks like the easy option rather than the right thing to do for the long-term.ldquoWe struggle to see how Musselburghrsquos five-star status can be sustainedsome of the workers who help make it what it is are losing their livelihoods, and it poses questions of the Chester management over their vision for the future of this course.Musselburgh Racecourse was run jointly by East Lothian Council and Lothians Racing Syndicate for more than a decade under the Musselburgh Joint Racing Committee.However, issues within the committee led to the British Horseracing Authority demanding an independent inquiry into its governance, which revealed a toxic relationship had developed between the two parties.The council set up Musselburgh Racing Associated Committeendash a new governance body ndash to oversee it as it sought a third-party operator to take over the management of the course.Staff at the racecourse at that point became council employees.When Chester took over on June , they transferred to the company.Mr Farnsworth said that the course finances had been hit by lockdown and, even when racing resumed behind closed doors, it was with no spectators or hospitality.He said: ldquoIt would be inappropriate to comment on the details but, like every racecourse in the country, we are having to review operational costs across the business in light of the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoThe reality is that since we resumed racing behind closed doors on June , we are a racecourse which is now racing again but without spectators, without hospitality revenues and with reduced sponsorship and media rights income.ldquoThe racecourse is unable to carry on as normal.ldquoLike every other business, be it in the sports, leisure, tourism, retail, professional services or industrial sectors, we are having to review everything we do in order to have a sustainable business, so that we can recover from the coronavirus pandemic.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, described the redundancies as ldquodeeply concerning.He said: ldquoThe change of ownership was meant to secure the course and the jobs, not threaten them.ldquoThese are dficult times but staff have maintained a marvellous facility before and during the crisis.ldquoThey are entitled to be treated better.ldquoIrsquoll be seeking assurances from the new management.

title: patrols-carried-human-waste-left-campers
story: Problems surrounding irresponsible campers were highlighted last month after reports of illegal fires being started and people leaving behind ldquotoilet paper and human waste.The disgusting image at Tyninghame Beach was highlighted by the countyrsquos countryside rangers.On Friday evening, with temperatures soaring across the country, they were joined by police officers in patrolling the beach.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed future patrols would also be carried out when the site was expected to be busy.She said: ldquoWe work closely with Police Scotland and other partners to manage responsible access to our coastal sites which includes matters such as parking capacity, wild camping and anti-social behaviour.ldquoOver the past months our countryside rangers have been carrying out patrols in and around our coastal sites engaging in particular with groups of campers.ldquoOn Friday, they were joined by colleagues from Police Scotland.ldquoThe purpose of these patrols is to provide information on responsible wild camping and behaviour in our countryside sites, and to discourage illegal camping and anti-social behaviour especially when it involves groups.ldquoWe intend to conduct these joint patrols over the busier weekends.Last month, countryside rangers revealed there had been an ldquounprecedented number of visitors along the East Lothian coast.The number was so large that some coastal car parks, including those at Tyninghame, Gullane and Yellowcraig, had to be closed.On one Saturday last month,  tents were found at Tyninghame, which equated to about  people camping in an area with no toilet facilities.Across East Lothian, more than  tents were found along the coastline.

title: delight-east-lothian-pupils-exam-results-u-turn
story: Exams were cancelled this year for students because of the coronavirus pandemic and teachers were asked to submit expected grades for each senior pupil based on prelim results and course work.However, the Scottish Qualications Authorityreviewed the submissions and using a lsquostatistical modelrsquo, which took into account the historic exam performances of schools, downgraded thousands of submitted grades, causing a national outrage.In East Lothian, , pupils received some grades which had been marked down.Only  of the , young people who were due to sit SQA exams had any of their final grades increased.The results dropped through letterboxes last Tuesday and sparked a furious backlash from students who received lower grades than expected.Erin Campbell, , Member of the Scottish Youth Parliamentfor Musselburgh, said many friends had been left worried and scared after the initial results came out, warning that the fiasco had been ldquobad for their mental health.Erin, who was a sixth-year student at Musselburgh Grammar School, said: ldquoOn a personal level, I was lucky to receive the results that I needed in order to move on to university however, I am aware of a lot of young people, including close friends, who were left scared and worried after not receiving a conditional offer to uni that was reliant on these results.ldquoThis badly impacted their mental health, particularly during the period of uncertainty before [Education Secretary] John Swinneyrsquos announcement [on Tuesday].Student protests were held in Glasgow and Edinburgh and politicians piled on pressure for the Scottish Government to step in and overturn the results.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray, Labourrsquos education spokesperson, called on Mr Swinney to resign after he initially backed the modied results before bending under pressure and telling the Scottish Parliament on Tuesday the Scottish Government had got it wrong.Mr Swinney said it was ldquodeeply regrettable we got this wrong and ordered the SQA to amend awards which had been marked down back to the submitted grade provided by teachers and reissue them.Mr Gray said Mr Swinney had spent five days defending the results before changing his position on Tuesday, asking him: ldquoWhy did he defend the results of this moderation for five days  Why did he leave these young people twisting in the wind for a week, hopes and aspirations in shreds Speaking after the decision, Mr Gray said: ldquoGiven the scale of the exam results scandal, it was inevitable that many local students would have been affected. I have certainly had a number of young people and parents contacting me over the last week to express their concerns about their grades being adjusted down by the SQA and the impact it might have on their futures.ldquoThe Scottish Governmentrsquos u-turn will bring relief to these worried young people and their families as they will now see their estimated results reinstated.ldquoHowever, the fact remains they should not have had to experience this worry and uncertainty in the first place. The Education Secretary has let them down and should be held accountable for this fiasco.Schools in East Lothian were yesterdaycontacting pupils who had been affected to let them know they would receive new awards.Across the county, , grades were submitted to the SQA for pupils at the end of May across National , Higher and Advanced Higher level by their teachers.In total, , were acceptedwith  adjusted upand ,adjusted down.In terms of pupils who were due to sit the exams, the council said just over  per cent saw at least one grade marked down.Councillor Shamin Akhtar , cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoIrsquom delighted that John Swinney has finally decided to do the right thing for pupils on the exam results fiasco.ldquoYoung people have faced a very tough and stressful time already and this is something they should never have had to go through.ldquoSchool staff worked extremely hard to submit grades for their pupils to the SQA and the adjustments undermined their professional judgement.ldquoThis u-turn is a victory for young people who have led the campaign against the unfair results and should be commended for standing up for their rights.And Councillor Craig Hoy , a member of East Lothianrsquos education committee, said: ldquoI am delighted that grades have been restored to hardworking pupils in East Lothian who faced huge uncertainty over the last week for no good reason.ldquoEveryone can see that John Swinney has presided over a litany of failures, any one of which could have been a resignation issue on its own.ldquoThe SNP defended their appalling grading system to the hilt, even after it became clear that pupils, parents and teachers had no confidence in the system.On Monday, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon issued an apology to students across the country who had been marked down by the SQA.She said: ldquoOur concern, which was to make sure the grades young people got were as valid as in any other year, perhaps led us to think too much about the overall system and not enough about the inidual pupil.ldquoThat has meant too many students feel they have lost out on grades they should have had, and that that has happened not as a result of anything they have done but a statistical model or algorithm.ldquoDespite our best intentions, I do acknowledge that we did not get this right and I am sorry.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council welcomed the u-turn, adding: ldquoThroughout this process our schools have sought to represent the academic achievements of our young people in a way that provided a fair and accurate reflection of attainment using the guidance and methodology provided by the SQA.ldquoThe announcement by the Education Secretary will be welcomed by young people who saw their results downgraded, and by our teachers and schools who used their professional judgement when providing grade estimates.East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskillpledged his support to headteachers in a letter at the end of last week after the original results came out.He said: ldquoI welcome the Scottish Governmentrsquos announcement.ldquoAs I said last week in a letter to East Lothianrsquos headteachers, I believe the people best placed to know about pupils are those overseeing and working alongside them during their academic journeys.ldquoThis decision is the right one, and I want to send my congratulations to all students in East Lothian for the work they have achieved both before and during this pandemic, as well as a huge thanks to the teachers and school support staff who have worked so hard over the last few months.

title: betrayal-claim-mcdonalds-musselburgh-recommended-approval
story: In a letter to the Courier, Fraser McAllister hit out at their ldquoillogical recommendation which,approved by councillors at an online meeting next week, would grant permission for a restaurant to be created in the car park of the Tesco store off Olivebank Road.He claimed that the drive-thru, which would operate  hours a day, seven days a week, would be ldquonext to the most congested roundabout in the county.The former SNP councillor for Musselburgh West said: ldquoTragically,  local objectors and , petitioners have less value than the share value of these gigantic corporations.He called on councillors on the planning committee, which will debate the proposal on Tuesday, to halt the ldquobetrayal.Mr McAllister also lodged a formal objection, citing a range of concerns including traffic congestion, pollution, litter, obesity, residential amenity and economic damage.He claimed: ldquoThe custom predicted for this -hour McDonaldrsquos drive-thru and the intensity of the declared deliveries needed to service it are on an industrial scale. The impact on Olivebank Road would be truly calamitous.The plan will go before a lsquovirtualrsquo meeting of the planning committee after being called off the delegated list by ward councillor Stuart Currie because of the level of local concern.He said: ldquoI have called this application off the list to ensure that all the concerns raised by local residents are discussed and elected members can understand not only the strength of feeling but also the planning issues that exist as a result of this application.Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council has lodged an objection, citing traffic congestion, emissions, and the facilityrsquos close proximity to local schools as concerns.A public campaign lsquoNo McDonaldrsquos in Musselburghrsquo was also launched in a bid to halt the plan, highlighting concerns such as increased traffic congestion, litter and air pollution.The planning report stated that there were  written representations to the application and, of these,  were objections.It said: ldquoThe councilrsquos road services advise they accept the conclusions of the traffic network modelling exercise, that the traffic impact associated with the proposed development would be minimal and there would be no adverse impact on the operation of the local highway network.ldquoMany written objections are made on the grounds of the proximity of the proposed drive-thru restaurant to Musselburgh Grammar School, and that such a facility promotes unhealthy eating and thus would lead to harmful health consequences.ldquoThe East Lothian Local Development Plan  does not contain any policies restricting the location of drive-thru restaurant facilities to a certain distance from schools, or any other educational establishments. Nor does it contain any policies relating to unhealthy eating or the health consequences of proposed developments. Thus, and in the absence of national guidance on health consequences of proposed developments, no signicant weight can be given to these matters.The report added: ldquoOn the matter of air quality, the public health and environmental protection officer advised that the proposed development was anticipated to result in up to  customer vehicles visiting the premises daily, which was a signicant number of additional vehicles given the proximity of site to the Air Quality Management Areaon Musselburgh High Street.The officer agreed with the conclusion of McDonaldrsquos Air Quality Assessment that impacts upon air quality at ldquosensitive receptors would not be signicant. The officer advised that, whilst it was acknowledged that additional traffic would have an impact upon queuing and reduce traffic speeds, the composition of the increased traffic would be from passenger cars, which are less polluting than HGVs and buses.The officer concluded that the proposed development would have ldquono harmful impact on air quality nor on the objectives of the AQMA and would not harm the amenity of the area.A McDonaldrsquos spokesperson said: ldquoWe look forward to progressing with this application and believe a new McDonaldrsquos would bring signicant investment to the local community, as well as create at least  new jobs.A supporting statement from the company added: ldquoThere are few restaurants in the country who can claim to have made so many positive changes to support healthier lestyles. McDonaldrsquos believe that the lessons they have learned in making these changes can be used to support a wider drive to reduce obesity.Planners are recommending the plan be approved with a number of conditions, including submission of litter and pest management plans.A council spokesperson declined to comment, saying the planning committee would consider the application next week.

title: coronavirus-forces-postponement-brunton-pantomime
story: Theatre organisers were looking forward to presenting the family favourite Aladdin during the festive period.But they have taken the ldquoextremely dficult decision to postpone the show until .A Brunton spokesperson said: ldquoThe Brunton is closely following Government advice as it becomes available.ldquoThe importance of having socially distanced measures in place once live performances are able to take place again will be crucial for the safety of our customers, staff, cast and freelance creative team.ldquoThese measures will mean that the audience size for live performances at The Brunton will be vastly reduced."The live interactive family experience which The Brunton panto delivers will also be affected.Last years pantomime was Cinderella.Michael Stitt, chairman of The Brunton Theatre Trust, said: ldquoIt is with great sadness that we announce the postponement of our  pantomime.ldquoThe Brunton panto is a much-loved tradition that is central to many peoplersquos festive celebrations ndash a tradition that we enjoy bringing to le every year.ldquoWe are aware that, although this is the right decision to take, it affects many ndash the cast, crew, and creatives that make the show every year, The Brunton staff and, of course, our wonderful audiences who join us to shout out at the baddies and laugh along with the dame.ldquoSo letrsquos think of it merely as a postponement, not a cancellation, of our treasured panto. title: letter-week-betrayal-mcdonalds-plan
story: Why obedience to the will of Tesco, the UKrsquos biggest supermarket land banking conglomerate and its aggressive alliance with the planetrsquos biggest takeaway empire  What happened to sustainability or compliance To cover themselves, council planners sought second traffic and pollution assessments. Not only will this fast food factory, with its  tables and three serving hatches, have no adverse impact on transport, parking, the environment or community amenity, it will actually solve existing problems!Thanks to  solicited reports using wizard modelling, this McDonaldrsquos will speed traffic flow by  likewise, any noise pollution on bad nights will be limited to one decibel. Phew! Advanced computer simulations prove that nitrogen dioxide and particle pollution will be ldquonegligible.The computer also says the average speed at Tesco roundabout, once this ldquoservice station opens, will be kph increasing to kph on the approaches. Yes folks, itrsquos a magic roundabout.The main report doesnrsquot quite say McDonaldrsquos is the answer to obesity and junk food addiction but comes close with descriptions of an exciting range of salads.No doubt these will feature prominently in the lunchtime ads pinged to smartphones at the Grammar from the predatory grease pit four minutes away.Teachers and PTAs remain silent because they are not free to speak but others have been less restrained. Parents, residents, our MP, MSP, Labour and SNP councillors, our community council, our area partnership and a multitude of civic groups have unanimously expressed their total opposition at .Tesco, which closed Alirsquos Cave and the last High Street butchers and fishmongers, now threatens the Caprice, other local restaurants, cafes and takeaways.Also, is Scotlandrsquos most important medieval bridge to be blighted for ever more by the ubiquitous burger symbol bathing it in a sickly neon yellow Tragically,  local objectors and , petitioners have less value than the share value of these gigantic corporations.There is no appeal: we can only trust the planning committee to halt this grotesque capitulation and betrayal.Fraser McAllisterMusselburgh

title: tour-europes-hot-spots-without-leaving-pencaitland
story: Residents and staff ndash or passengers and cabin crew ndash are recreating a European holiday, stopping off at popular hotspots on a two-month cruise ndash all without leaving Pencaitland and without getting their feet wet.Boarding passes in hand, the passengers of the Tyneholm Estate cruise liner have been enjoying the virtual holiday of a letime, exploring traditional flavours and cultures of eight faraway destinations.Captain Ann Lyell, care home manager, said that the crew were pulling out all the stops to ensure a memorable holiday.She said: ldquoNot many people would believe you can experience genuine holiday moments in a care home, but those people have never been on a Sanctuary Care Cruise.ldquoAnd this is not just a holiday for our residents, but also my team.ldquoEach week, we are bringing the European destinations into our home through amazing food, fun and inspiring excursions, and the cabin crew are playing their part perfectly.ldquoI honestly canrsquot put into words how wonderfully creative the past weeks have been, and we are all so looking forward to the rest of our European tour ndash especially our residents, some of whom have never been abroad before!ldquoWe are not only enriching lives, we are creating new le experiences ndash how amazing is that As part of the virtual cruise initiative, cabin crew are provided with weekly staff handbooks, props and supporting literature, so they can deliver traditional festivities with real authenticity.And the travel calendar is bursting at the seams, with highlights including dancing, crafting, baking, tasting, drawing, quizzing, learning and celebrating, as well as a range of festivals.Passengers and crew started off in Portugalrsquos capital city, Lisbon, and enjoyed port tasting and Azulejo tile creating at the beginning of July.The following week, the ship headed for Malaga in Spain, with Sangria making and Picasso line-drawing.Since then, the trip through the Mediterranean has continued with stops at Nice in France ndash where artists such as Claude Monet and Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot were celebrated ndash Rome, where passengers got the chance to explore Italian operas, bocce and pizza-making, and Valletta in Malta, where the cabin crew hosted their own Feast of St Paulrsquos Shipwreck Festival, complete with homemade Maltese decorations and crowns.The next stop is Athens, where the cruise liner todayand tomorrowis hosting its very own Greek-inspired celebrations, including Greek gods and Olympic-themed activities.From there, it is on to Limassol in Cyprus, and finally Istanbul in Turkey.First-class passenger Douglas MacKay is one of the residents enjoying the trip.He added: ldquoThe cruise has been great so far never did I think at my age I would be cruising with so many amazing people.Fellow passenger and resident Jane Barclay described the virtual trip as ldquosuch good fun.She said: ldquoWho says we are too old to have a good time, and at least I donrsquot get sick from the sea either.

title: six-primary-schools-start-new-year-acting-headteachers
story: East Lothian Council has started the recruitment process to find new headteachers at a number of schools.At Musselburgh Burgh Primary School, Jon Doyle, depute headteacher, will step up to becoming acting headteacher.Karen Fleming retired from the role of headteacher at the end of the last school term.Mr Doyle will take on the role of acting headteacher during the recruitment process and until a new permanent headteacher is appointed.Alison Cameron, headteacher at Elphinstone Primary School, will be in charge at Humbie and Saltoun Primary Schools as well.The acting headteacher will continue to oversee the schools in Humbie and East Saltoun until a permanent headteacher is appointed.Mags McBean will also become acting headteacher at St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School in Prestonpans following the retirement of Anne Torley ahead of the summer holidays.Mrs McBean is also the headteacher at Loretto RC Primary School in Musselburgh and will lead St Gabrielrsquos RC until a permanent appointment is made.Meanwhile, at West Barns Primary School, Laura Hay, currently acting depute headteacher, will become acting headteacher.Ronnie Taylor, who was acting headteacher, willto his substantive role as headteacher of Innerwick and Stenton Primary Schools.Mrs Hay will be acting headteacher during Gill Whitfordrsquos continuing secondment within East Lothian Councilrsquos early years team.Finally, Fiona Macartney will continue with the current arrangement as acting headteacher at Whitecraig Primary School, while continuing as headteacher at Musselburghrsquos Stoneyhill Primary School.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThis will be until such time as we recruit and appoint a new headteacher for Whitecraig Primary School.

title: preston-athletic-players-swap-boots-bicycles-fundraiser
story: Members of Preston Athletic FCrsquos squad got on their bikes to raise money for the club and the NHS on Saturday, August .A dozen players, as a relay team, cycled from Dunbar Unitedrsquos New Countess Park through East Lothian, Midlothian and Edinburgh before reaching the finish line at their home ground, the Pennypit.Kai Austin was among those setting off from the Seasidersrsquo ground at about am but had to make a quick substitution before kick-off.He said: ldquoI had not checked my bike for about a week beforehand.ldquoI was putting it into the car and noticed the back tyre was flat.ldquoI thought we would pump it up when we got there.ldquoAfter we arrived, my girlfriend drove away and I was walking along and noticed the tyre was flat again.Fortunately, one of Kairsquos team-mates for the cycle had a spare bike and they were quickly able to get on the open road.The fundraiser came about with players deciding to visit  football grounds ndash the home of  teams ndash ahead of the   season.The first stop was at Millfield , before going on to Foresters Parkand New Recreation Park .The second group of cyclists ventured into Midlothian and ticked off Kingrsquos Park , Newbattle Complex , New Victoria Park , Newbyres Park , New Dundas Parkand Ferguson Park .Nathan Stokes, who plays in midfield and up front, was among the third group, who completed the Midlothian section by travelling on to Penicuik Park .Then it was into the Capital and Paties Road , Meggetland , Saughton Enclosureand Christie Gillies Park .Finally, the Edinburgh section was complete with a visit to Ainslie Park Stadium , St Marks Parkand Peffermillbefore ing to East Lothian and Olivebankand the Pennypit.Nathan, , said: ldquoTo get to Peffermill, we came down Cameron Toll.ldquoFrom the Commonwealth Pool, it is all downhill and by that point my legs were screaming.ldquoFor me, it was a nice relaxing run down there and when we reached Peffermill we knew it was only  minutes to Musselburgh and then another - minutes to the Pans. Getting to East Lothian was definitely a psychological boost.The cyclists finished at the Pennypit shortly after pm, where they were met by the participants from the earlier legs.Right-back Kai, who lives just metres from the ground in Prestonpans, was among those at the finish line. He said: ldquoWe had the people that did the cycle and some people there that were not able to do it because of injury.ldquoThe club put on a socially distanced get-together and put on some sausage rolls and pies.ldquoWe were sitting in the stand and were there for them arriving and cheered them in.Nathan, of Wallyford, was delighted to reach the finish line, with the cyclists completing  kilometres over the eight hours.He added: ldquoThe aim was to get pound, and then we raised pound,.ldquoWe are really chuffed and ideally I would like to raise another pound so the cash is split into pound each.ldquoI think I was chuffed and on Saturday Hearts tweeted us and wished us luck.ldquoWe have got a few Hearts fans in the team so they were happy.To support the good cause, go to justgiving crowdfunding prestonathletic

title: schools-forever-former-wallyford-primary-comes
story: Edinburgh-based Kinetic Demolition was tasked with the job at the site on Salters Road, which started last month and is expected to take  weeks to complete.The school, built in , was replaced with a new pound. million primary school on the outskirts of the village on Futures Way.Mr Bathgate, a Wallyford resident and keen local historian, said the former school replaced the first village school, which dated from  and was sited next to it on Salters Road where houses now stand. title: east-lothians-six-childrens-hubs-close-summer-holidays
story: More than  staff helped support the hubs through the summer holidays after switching from their normal roles to support the emergency measures.East Lothian Council openedsix hubs across its main towns, reducing them to four during school holidays as required.The council said the hubs not only supported key workers and carers but also vulnerable children and those with complex needs.Staff from schools, nurseries, library services, countryside rangers and more offered to help run the hubs, providing for hundreds of youngsterswho attended.During the summer, senior pupils from secondary schools were also able to help out.Monica Patterson, council chief executive, said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank staff from across the council and our partners who did such a fantastic job in initially establishing and then maintaining the hubs, including provision during school holidays.ldquoI recognise that a huge amount of planning, preparation and day-to-day support has been provided and Irsquom pleased that this has benefited many families by enabling key worker parents and carers to continue working, while continuing to support children and young people with complex additional support needs.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoI know that many parents and carers have valued the support provided by our childrenrsquos hubs since March.ldquoPutting emergency learning and childcare in place was incredibly supportive, and we couldnrsquot have done it without the hard work and commitment of so many staff from across a number of dferent teams and services across the council and from some of our partners.

title: children-left-without-water-school-rules-confusion
story: Confusion over new guidelines introduced across East Lothian schools as youngsters ed saw children in some schools told they could not refill their personal water bottles unless there was a tap in their classroom.It meant that by lunchtime on Wednesday, as temperatures soared into the mid s across East Lothian, a number of children had emptied their bottles.Parents took to social media with reports of primary school children collected from school parched and complaining of headaches after they were told they could not get more water.One mother revealed that her nine-year-old son was refused a chance to refill his bottle after running out of water in the morning and told he could not leave his desk, which was directly under a window with the sun streamingin.She said: "If this was a prison and inmates were refused access to water in the heat there would be an outcry, so why were our children treated like this "Campaigning group Us For Them Scotland later named three East Lothian schools - Musselburgh Grammar School, Haddington Primary School and Campie Primary School in Musselburgh -among a list of Scottish schools where there had been complaints about children being refused access to water.East Lothian Council said that access to water was available in all schools and schools had been given further clarication on the guidelines.A spokesperson said: "Access to drinking water is available in all of our schools."We are encouraging all families to send their child to school with a ready-filled water bottle ndash families were advised to contact their school in advancethere would be an issue providing one."Refill opportunities are available, with the most appropriate method having been determined by inidual schools to best meet their setting. This means all children have access to drinking water."Our schools have put a huge amount of work into a safefor all children and young people, and will continue to monitor how well their arrangements are working."We have worked with our schools to clary guidance and put in place measures that will make sure all children and young people have opportunities to top-up drinking water throughout the day."Parents on social media said their children had also been unable to access water yesterday.One parentsaid: "This also happened to my son today, who came home and said he was so thirsty he felt light-headed."Another local added: "My two grandsons said the same when we picked them up, both were gasping on a drink. My daughters sending them with extra water bottles tomorrow."Other parents said that the problem occured at a number of schools, pointing out that some children attended breakfast clubs and after-school clubs, meaning even with an extra bottle they had to make it last for nine hours.Another asked of teaching staff: "If you can grab a takeaway latte from Costa, why cant they refill the wee ones water bottles "However, others defended the teaching staff, pointing out that emails to parents had made those whose children would not be able to refill water bottles during the day aware and that schools were "on a learning curve" with new ways of working.At Campie Primary School in Musselburgh, where concerns were also raised on Wednesday, it is understood that teachers went round the classrooms with jugs of fresh water in the afternoon and planned to do that again.Us For Them Scotland organiser Johannah Bisset said: "Even cattle have a legal right to water. Yet somehow our children have had that right stripped away from them.ldquoThis decision once again demonstrates the utter disregard these decision-makers have for the wellbeing of our children."Children all over Scotland are writing to the First Minister to ask her to provide water for all of Scotlandrsquos children. We have great hopes that she will respond positively to protect our children."

title: new-bbc-documentary-series-jamie-genevieve-great-indoors-air-week
story: The make-up artist, who is a worldwide star on YouTube and Instagram, will star in the three-part series Jamie Genevieve: Great Indoors on BBC Scotland onThursday at . pm.It comes after the success of her first documentary for the networks BBC Scotland channel Jamie Genevieve #Unfiltered.The former Cathkin High School pupil started out working in make-up counters in Debenhams in Glasgow.Now she is known for her how to make-up demonstrations on YouTube.The new mini-series focuses on how Jamie and husband Jack is coping in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic from trying her hand at hairdressing to baking.

title: 5-new-books-read-week
story: Emma DonoghuePicador, priced pound. Emma Donoghue wrote this startling and extraordinary novel before the coronavirus pandemic hit ndash but it couldnt be more prescient. The Pull Of The Stars takes place across three days in , where on a makesht, thoroughly understaffed maternity ward in Dublin, Nurse Julia Power is trying to support pregnant women through labour, while Spanish Influenza goes about its insidious, fatal work. Eerie comparisons with Covid asideJulias observations on the odds pregnant women in poverty already face, and the havoc wreaked on their bodies from having too many children, too young, is devastating - and fascinating - to read.Donoghue deftly weaves in politics, policy, the impact of war, feminism, violence and the minutiae of changing bed pans and sterilising instruments, while dealing with dismissive male doctors and birthing babies. And thats all alongside the awful things happening in Irish convents and childrens homes. But throughout, the pragmatic, thoughtful Julia keeps the overwhelming darkness shes tackling, in abeyance - just about. A powerful, persistent, highly detailed and incredibly moving book that speaks through time. Donoghue is an absolute marvel of a writer.Ella WalkerMiss Bensons BeetleRachel JoyceDoubleday, priced pound. The latest book from the bestselling author of The Unlikely Pilgrimage of Harold Fry is about an expedition to find the golden beetle of New Caledonia. Set in the stultied s, Miss Bensons Beetle considers female friendship in the unlikeliest of situations. Miss Benson, a frumpy, middle-aged domestic science teacher hiding a letimes worth of emotional scars from herself, suffers one slight too many and behaves in a completely irrational manner. This prompts her to revive a childhood dream, in a now or never moment to find the golden beetle. She advertises for an assistant and an unlikely candidate steps forward - Enid Pretty. The pair have nothing in common, but through a series of sometimes farcical, sometimes poignant adventures together, a redemptive bond is created between the women. But danger is never far away. To survive, the pair need to find their best selves. While a little uneven in tone, youll find yourself willing the pair to succeed, escape the chains of their previous lives, and find their true self worth.Bridie PritchardMy Darling from The LionsRachel LongPicador, priced pound. My Darling From The Lions is the debut collection from poet Rachel Long. Founder of the Octavia Poetry Collective for Womxn of Colour, Long focuses on womens experiences, race and heritage, all intertwined in the recurring mot of hair and wigs, used in the title of one of the collections three sections - A Lineage of Wigs. The collection also covers relationships, religion, family and school, skilfully highlighting the tension between the latter when describing day-long hair styling in Jail Letter: "Mum, my scalp burns! Ungrateful! Look at you, beautul as Winnie Mandela! I dont know who this is but it doesnt sound like someone Ben Clark will fancy." Longs use of dialect is one of her strongest points , while one of the most effective poems, , uses form to indicate a skipping and speeding memory of abuse.Laura Paterson

title: create-seaside-themed-garden
story: Award-winning garden designer Joe Perkins, who lives close to the sea in Brighton, and Lynette Talbot, chairperson of Sidmouth In Bloom, offer their tips on how you can recreate beach vibes in your outdoor space...Set the scene with sandy soil or gravel"Ideally, youd need sandy soil or a gravel footpath. Gravel gardens can make it look like a beach," says Cha Gold medallist Perkins, whose  Facebook show garden Growing The Future will be displayed at next years show."You could do worse than put down four or five inches of gravel, and many seaside plants would be happy growing in it. If you have poor drainage or heavy soil, build up a gravel layer, adding sand or soil to add nutrients.:Letters: When it comes to language, lets live and let live"A lot of coastal plants will be perfectly happy growing into that layer and many of them dont need much soil, andthey do, like sea kale, they will have a deep tap root which theyll send down to stabilise themselves.""Treat your seaside garden like an alpine garden," says Talbot. "You want free-draining soil, which you can build up like a rockery or clf face, incorporating shorter grasses like carex or small miscanthus, to give you the feel of the wispy grasses along the edge of the shoreline."Pick suitable plants"If you like the spartan look, you could make a gravel garden planted with rivers of thyme, dwarf myrtle bushes and some evening primrose coming through it."Stock up on free-draining species"Other good plants to create a sea feel would include santolinas, lavenders, silver-leaf plants and some sea poppies, which need to be planted in a very free-draining, gritty soil, with a good sand and compost mix because they dont like being in a very fertile garden. Known as the horned poppy, these perennials have lemon flowers and large, bean-like seed heads," continues Talbot.:Herald Diary: Getting to grips with a Titanic struggle"Thrtis another good choice and comes in colours from white to darkish red. You can buy any of the Ballerina Series in the alpine section of a local nursery." She also recommends sea holly , sedums, artemisia and mallows.For border colour, you could go with acanthus, euphorbias, Phlomis russelianaand valerian , erigeronand low-growing herbs such as thyme, lavender and rosemary, Perkins suggests.Add seaside accessories"Create a small area with some shingle and put some posts on the side, with a rope link between them or some firemens buckets or tyres or rings which could be painted red to resemble lebuoys, or get some glass fishermens jars. You might be able to get hold of some crayfish or lobster baskets, which give an area a nice seaside feel," Talbot advises."Thick ropes, which you often see tying a boat to a mooring, are a great accessory. You can get a garden-sized boat and plant that up, putting it on a small shingle bed, with alpine grit over the top to finish."Display beach finds carefullyPerkins says you have to be careful when putting shells or drtwood youve found on beach-combing walks on display at random points in the garden. "Instead of dotting things around, make a display cabinet of perhaps a series of shells, which makes sense of them being there."Create a beach-inspired social spot"For me, being on the beach is about getting together in the evening and relaxed social gatherings, so I would think about fire pits, deck chairs and that sort of low-slung seating you can really relax into. Fire pits are great, whether you choose gas or wood fire," Perkins observes.Hammocks and outdoor bean bags could also be added to create that beach feel, he suggests.

WARNING: This picture must only be used to accompany PA Feature TRAVEL Braemar.The Aberdeen-born poet and writer, whose face now adorns the Scottish pound note, made it her les quest to find the "essential nature" of the Cairngorms. In the process of exploring its graceful, gleaming rivers and high plateaus "as delectable as honey", she discovered a lot about herself too.Twice the size of the Lake District, East Scotlands Cairngorms National Park is a wilderness area of crisp, clear lochs, ancient forests and glens bristling with vibrant purple heather. Promising calm, quiet and the freedom of space, it seemed an obvious choice for a post-lockdown adventure with my mum, Gabriella.Aged over  and recovering from heart surgery, my mum had been shielding since March. Im not a fan of Zoom or FaceTime, so when we met at Heathrow airport to catch our flight to Aberdeen, it was the first time Id seen her in four months.In a world where every move seems to be dominated by Covid-, the decision to travel isnt an easy one to make at any age. But as days disappear and months march on, theres an urgency to get moving. Ive never really understood why time accelerates with age. The harder we grip, the more it slips away. Maybe its the realisation that everything is finite, including us.Then there was the risk of being indefinitely confined by anxiety."If I dont go out soon, Ill never have the confidence," my mum confessed.So, armed with face masks, sanitiser and a sensible degree of caution, we refused to be beaten by fear.Nan chose to camp her way around the Cairngorms. But weve opted for a greater degree of comfort at the Fe Arms, a regal Victorian property in the village of Braemar on the banks of the River Clunie, matched in magnicence to its surrounding mountain landscape.After having our temperatures checked, were ushered inside by the hotels welcoming ghillies who apologise profusely for the impersonality of Perspex  on reception, visors and the absence of Fes bespoke tartan blankets in rooms.Scotland only recently emerged from lockdown on July , and the hotel Is quickly adapting to a new and unfamiliar way of working. Rooms are deep cleaned between guests, breakfast buffets have been ditched in favour of timed sittings, and a one-way system is in place throughout the property.Otherwise, it all feels refreshingly normal.Owned by art dealers Iwan and Manuela Wirth , who breathed new le into its rundown shell and re-opened in , the Fe is filled with , artworks, antiques and collectables.When youve been indoors for so long, everything has a new and shiny appeal. But here in this Disneyland of culture and creativity, my mum has the wide-eyed wonder of a child embracing infinity and beyond.Paying homage to Braemars Victorian roots, furnishings reflect the grandeur of that time: an ornately carved walnut wood fireplace depicting works by Scottish poet Robert Burns dominates the reception chairs upholstered in Liberty fabrics decorate the drawing room and natural history specimens are displayed in curiosity cabinets, or used to create whimsical tableaux in bell jars. Not to everyones modern PC tastes, one corridor alone has  pieces of taxidermy, upstaged only by an eery waxwork model of Queen Victoria in the library, purchased from Madame Tussauds.If a wall of stags heads is isive, modern artworks incorporating antlers are pleasingly palatable: hanging above the main staircase, Richard Jacksons Red Deer Chandelier is a tangle of neon bagpipe drones and glass antlers.From outspoken sculptures to understated sketches, every corner of the Fe is covered in conversation-provoking art.Works by Picasso, Brueghel The Younger and Man Ray hang on walls one of Louise Bourgeois bronze spiders straddles the courtyard. But an even more impressive find are some watercolours of royal estates painted by Prince Charles and a sketch by Queen Victoria of a stag shot by her close confidant John Brown.Braemars relationship with royalty reaches back to  when Prince Albert purchased Balmoral Estate for his sovereign we. "She was passionate about this place," Katy Fennema of Braemar Highland Experience tells me. The former musician, whose family have  years of history in the area, now runs local history, wilderness and wildle tours with her husband, Julian.During a morning driving tour, she shares tales of brigands hung from tree boughs, and delights in stories of Chanels fashion rival Elsa Schiaparelli, who became fascinated with Braemar when her friend, Vogue editor Frances Lovell Oldham, married a laird. The two ladies would literally go on to paint parts of the town shocking pink, and an art deco bar at the Fe is named after Elsa.Much of the land here has been shaped by aristocracy. Patchworks of charred heather on the hillside are the remnants of controlled burns, used to boost a grouse population in time for shoots.Yet so much remains wild. Along the Queens Drive walking trail, trees are laden with tufty beards of lichen, an indicator of the airs purity.At .am one morning, mum and I ramble through the Morrone Birkwood, a relic of deciduous woodland that once covered the Cairngorms. On the way up, we watch hares and red squirrels scamper through a stadium used to host the Braemar Gathering, one of the most popular Highland Games. And we detour past the house where Robert Louis Stephenson spent a miserable, rainy three months in , emerging with the first  chapters of Treasure Island.Its a very dferent scene today. Sunlight splinters through gate pickets as we clamber onto a trail scattered with pinecones. Streams trickle melodically from the mountainside and the scent of honeysuckle is dizzying.Juniper, blaeberries, meadowsweet and yarrow - so many plants thrive in this healthy environment. Later in the day, herbalist and forager Natasha Lloyd introduces us to her open-air medicine cabinet. She recommends treatments for my mums liver, and I learn how to eat a raw nettle without getting stung. The common nettle is packed with Vitamin D, which may boost the immune system against respiratory viruses such as Covid-.Fortunately, there were no cases of coronavirus in Braemar. Although one famous figure down the road made headlines: Prince Charles self-isolated at Balmoral when he fell ill at the beginning of lockdown.Its easy to see why the royals come here to escape and recuperate. This month, the Queen will arrive for her annual summer holiday. We follow one of her favourite trails through the Ballochbuie Forest, a protected tract of -year-old pines saved from felling by Queen Victoria, leading to the Honka Hut - a simple cabin where Elizabeth II likes to picnic.In the past, hikers claim to have "run-into" Her Royal Highness walking the corgis, but blissfully, we dont see a soul.It was silence and solitude that guided Nan Shepherd into the mountains. Similarly, it helps my mum readjust to an outside world fraught with complications, but beautul at its core.How to plan your tripRooms at the Fe Arms start from poundin a Croft Room. For more information or to book, visit thefearms.

title: young-adult-book-review-perks-wallflower-stephen-chbosky
story: What is the book about The story takes place in a series of letters written to an unknown figure by Charlie, a shy and empathetic teenager with a deep love of books and music over the period of his first year at high school. He makes friends with a group of seniors who help him to feel young and infinite, and has a kind English teacher that gives him extra books to read and write about. It focuses on the themes of family, friendship, first love and the journey of recovery from mental health issue.Who is it aimed at To those around  and  or older.What was your favourite part I loved everything about Charliersquos character. Often coming of age novels are written from the perspective of those who are already bold and adventurous at the beginning but this one is dferent. Watching someone develop into more of an active participant in their own youth without changing themselves entirely to be more extroverted is refreshing and heart warming.What was your least favourite part Itrsquos easy to get attached to the characters, and though this is one of the best things, the downside is that with the heavier ideas of mental illness and abuse, come possibly a few tears.Which character would you most like to meet There was never a moment where it lost track of Charlie. His voice was in every page and I would love to hear more.Why should someone buy this book This book is in every way inspiring, emotional and insightful.GEMMA McLAUGHLIN

title: Opinion  Iain Macwhirter  All shall have prizes in the great exams U-turn     except John Swinney
story: Mr Swinney cast aside the independent Scottish Qualications Authority and their wretched algorithms, and restored the very estimated exam grades which he, and the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon had said only last week were ldquonot credible.All upgraded results will stand all , downgraded results will be reversed. Everyone wins. And all shall have prizes.:IndyRef: New poll shows % would back independence as SNP set for record Holyrood majorityMind you, I dont think Mr Swinney will be interfering in many future examinations. I cant think of any ministerial U-turn that has been quite as humiliating as this one. Not least because Mr Swinney spent half of his statement defending the very moderation system that he had just discarded.No serious government can conduct its business in this way. Mr Swinney gave no principled explanation of why he was abandoning the work of the supposedly independent SQA ndash other than that a number young people felt that the system was unjust. That is undeniably true and we all felt for them.But this capitulation leaves the SQA in an impossible position, and brings the whole examination process into question. Indeed, I dont see how the SQA can continue in its present form. Certainly, it cannot conduct its normal moderation of exam results with any confidence in future years.And nor can Mr Swinney. He must surely go now, after this fiasco, and without delay. Someone must come in to restore respect for the standards in Scottish education and serve the last rites on the Qualications Authority.Indeed, standardised assessment through competitive examinations looks to have had its day. As Mr Swinney hinted, it has become increasingly unpopular in recent years. Though every country including Finland, the leading edge of pedagogical progressivism, uses objective testing.But after this fiasco, examinations like the Highers will surely lose their unique status and will likely be supplanted by teacher estimates of ability which, according to Mr Swinney, is the most reliable way to gauge academic achievement. This, even though he himself concedes that in the past teacher assessment has been no reliable guide to exam performance.The impact on grade inflation will be as the First Minister herself forecast last week ldquoincredible. A % increase in Highers grades means that this years students will forever be marked out as the year when exam credibility went out the window.Whoever called the process by which the Scottish Qualication Authority adjusts exam scores to reflect past school performance ldquomoderation had a dry sense of humour. It has caused fury amongst teachers, pupils, parents.The anger shows no sign of moderating even after Swinneys desperate attempt to put a lid on the worst exam crisis in  years. This was a statement that was as humiliating as it was self-contradictory.:UK falls into recession after lockdown sees record contractionHe began by explaining atwhy the moderation applied by the SQA did not disproportionately downgrade students from deprived areas, as has been widely claimed. This is because the grade inflation, against historic standards, was higher in schools in these areas, at %, than in schools in more prosperous areas, which inflated by only around %. Greater moderation was therefore applied out of fairness, not classism.He then commended the SQAs ldquoopen and transparent adjustment methodology and insisted that it was ldquoin use throughout the UK and across the world". But, er, not in Scotland any more. Mr Swinney then let the algorithmic cat out of the bag by pointing out that exam moderation happens every year to some extent as the SQA, and its English equivalent Ofqual, manipulate grade boundaries. But not presumably in future.He even announced, solemnly, that the remit of the SQAwas to ensure that every student got ldquothe qualications they deserved. The teacher estimates: ldquo awarded without moderation, he said ldquo would have led to an increase in pass rates without precedent.Sothe methodology was so fair and robust, why was he over-ruling the independent SQA and allowing this unprecedented grade inflation to take place  Well, Mr Swinney had spoken to young people who felt ldquotheir future was being determined by statistical modelling. The credibility of exam grades was of secondary importance to ldquothe risk that people would lose faith in the system. Well, they certainly will now.But does anyone seriously think that the SQA actually marked down working class students because they were living in a deprived postcode  Of course not. The SQA anyway subjected its moderation regime to an Equalities Impact Assessment ndash as it is obliged to do ndash before it published them.Moderation by algorithm is a pretty blunt instrument and doesnt take account of inidual performance. But, as Mr Swinney says, it is very widely used. Capitulating to grade inflation of up to % may win political points in the short term, but it will store up big problems for the future.:John Swinneys SQA U-Turn: Seven things you need to knowEvery year, grade boundaries move up and down to ensure fairness and comparable outcomes. Tens of thousands of pupils have their exam results routinely moderated. The English equivalent of the SQA, Ofqual, uses a very similar ldquostandardisation model against which to correct scores which depart from the historical average.Englands pandemic moderation is, according to reports, even greater than ours ndash % of grades have been adjusted downwards from the estimates provided by teachers, against % in Scotland. We wont know the final figures until tomorrowwhen the English A level results are unveiled. But, strangely, there has not been anything like the controversy over moderation that we have seen here.The inconvenient truth is that the Scottish ldquopandemic cohort, as they are already being dubbed, has exchanged one unfairness for another. They may have got the grades they and their teachers wanted, but those grades will forever be tainted by the chaotic and unprincipled way in which they were awarded. Handed to them by an Education Secretary in panic mode who said he had no right to interfere in examination results. And then proceeded to do just that.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: five-new-albums-listen-week
story: DREAMLANDThe latest showing from electronic indie four-piece Glass Animals is a psychedelic trip down memory lane, with bass-heavy beats and introspective lyrics.Dreamland is the bands third studio album and combines their distinctive electro-pop sound with influences ranging from the Beach Boys to Timbaland.Frontman Dave Bayley says inspiration for the album came at a time of "confusion and uncertainty" , when he found it easier to look to the past rather than the future.The popular single Heatwaves, released in June, is a prime example of such reflection - with lyrics perfectly capturing the feel of obsessive young relationships: Sometimes all I think about is you  Late nights in the middle of June.Big electronic drum beats feature throughout the album but a whimsical, nostalgic vibe creeps in through lighter synths and twanging guitar on the title track Dreamland, and Melon And The Coconut.A standout track is Your Love , released back in February, which pays tribute to the production styles of Justin Timberlake and Missy Elliot with its driving beat and dance-y melody.As well as being rammed with enormous tunes, the wistful, throwback lyrics make Dreamland an apt and strong contender for one of the major sounds of an unconventional summer.Mike BediganMADE OF RAINTHE PSYCHEDELIC FURSMade Of Rain, the first album from The Psychedelic Furs in  years, proves the new wave darlings havent lost their edge.In recent years the group have reformed on a semi-regular basis to play live dates.But they said they had begun to "feel like a jukebox" and set about writing new material to bolster their sets.The Furs sported a rotating line-up throughout the s, anchored by the presence of brothers Richard and Tim Butler.They released a cluster of seminal records including s Mirror Moves but towards the end of the decade the quality began to drop off.Made Of Rain recaptures some of the heady glamour of their early albums, and a fair dose of their swagger.It is also a markedly darker affair ndash and thats saying something for the band that inspired The Horrors and Interpol.Pounding drums, soaring synths and brooding vocals are all present, but most importantly, the songs are just excellent.Alex GreenWASHED OUTPURPLE NOONA decade on from the heyday of the microgenre known as chillwave, Atlantas Ernest Greene s with his fourth album as Washed Out.Opening track Too Late sounds instantly familiar, mid-tempo, muffled vocals conveying a vague sense of unease and regret, s drums, washes of synths.With the shock of the new long gone, this laid-back, tasteful sound seems more like yacht rock than the cutting edge, and can easily blend into the background.Chillwave always tends to be described as summertime music, hazy and shimmering, and, listening during a heatwave, Purple Noon ticks all those boxes - the title comes from the sunbaked Mediterranean  film based on The Talented Mr Ripley.The single Time To Walk Away isfaster and insidiously catchy, the sort of earworm that re-emerges days later with you wondering what it is, and how it got there.But too many of the tracks struggle to hold the attention, with Greenes -year journey from scratchy lo-fi to polished textures inspired by Sade and Phil Collins ending in a bland cul-de-sac.Matthew GeorgeJON ANDERSON, HANDSJon Andersons latest solo album,you can call it that, has been a long time in the making.Originally conceived  years ago during a songwriting retreat in Calornias Big Bear Mountain area, the original tapes were left to languish in Andersons garage.But two years ago the co-founder and former lead singer of progressive rock pioneers Yes was approached by producer Michael Franklin who had enough capital to complete the project.Anderson recruited a bevvy of friends, admirers and personal heroes to work on the tracks, including Jethro Tulls Ian Anderson and pianist Chick Corea .It also features archive recordings from Andersons former Yes bandmates - drummer Alan White and bassist Chris Squire, the latter having died in  from a rare form of leukaemia.Theres prog-rock wig-outs in Activate and Come Up, while First Born Leaders delivers reggae rhythms with a hallucinogenic edge.Andersons brand of prog-rock, psychedelia and world music may no longer be cool, hip or even groovy, but his magnetic charm and free-wheeling musicality is enough to lend , Hands some weight.Alex GreenLAYLA KAYLIFLOVERS DONT MEETBritish singer-songwriter Layla Kayl draws on Shakespeare, the work of th century Persian poet Rumi and US country music on her latest album.Sound like a lot, right  But at seven tracks, Lovers Dont Meet is short and sweet.Kayls voice is warm and graceful and the guitar work simple and direct.Its a heady mix and one that benefits from the pleasing production she secured during recording sessions in Nashville with producer Jason Hall.Lovers Dont Meet pays homage to a genre Kayl has always loved, but it fails to replicate the soul or substance of true country music.Instead, Kayl fills up the album with references - to the queen of country Dolly Parton on Dont You Know Me Yet  and th century Syrian writer Nizar Qabbani on As I Am.The result is a little messy, but enjoyable nonetheless.Alex Green

title: agenda-business-needs-support-preventing-covid-spikes
story: AS Aberdeen residents and businesses weather the cityrsquos second lockdown, itrsquos time for fresh thinking on how we manage the Covid- challenge to protect public health and prevent further damage to the economy.Further lockdowns are devastating to peoplersquos livelihoods, destroying businesses and adversely impacting on any hope for a short-term economic recovery, and must be avoided at all cost. While the Scottish Government, which is ultimately responsible for safeguarding public health, has a major role to play, I believe businesses are better placed to make things happen and to do so far more quickly.The best way forward should involve a new approach with business taking the lead to implement greater safety measures with the support of government and other public sector bodies.This will start with business owners and managers stepping up and being more proactive in ensuring they operate within a safer framework to stop the spread of this virus. As well as providing a clean and safe environment for their customers at all times, they will also need to consider implementing other creative measures and better utilising existing technology.We are already seeing a number of examples of this across the globe where businesses are driving forward on-the-ground initiatives to reduce the risk of a further lockdown. Restaurants in Kinsale, in County Cork, Ireland have, for example, begun testing the temperatures of all their customers upon entry. Meanwhile Tourism Portugal has introduced ldquoSafe  Clean certication which enables participating hotels to provide the reassurance they have undertaken the appropriate level of disinfecting and have made hand sanitiser available to guests throughout their stay. Even McDonaldrsquos has gone beyond government guidelines by making the wearing of masks mandatory for all customers entering any of their , US restaurants.While businesses in Aberdeen and throughout Scotland should be taking the lead in bringing new and effective measures to fruition, the support of the Scottish Government will be essential as well as beneficial. Agencies including Scottish Enterprise, where we have made initial representations on this issue, could provide grants and other support measures. This could help many hard-pressed businesses put temperature monitoring devices for both staff and customers as well as other facilities in place at a time when the strain on their finances may otherwise prevent such expenditure. This would put even more pressure on the public purse, but it would be a sensible investmentit prevents the economic carnage that comes from further lockdowns.Nicola Sturgeonrsquos leadership has been solid throughout much of this pandemic. If she is serious about Scotland rebuilding its economy she should require business to take a greater role in proactively preventing the risk of further outbreaks of the pandemic but also provide the appropriate support to enable it to do this.Andrew Montague is CEO of ClearWater Hygiene

title: opinion-mark-smith-scotland-finally-something-inglorious-tradition
story: But could they be a threatened species  The Scottish Governmentrsquos Werritty report on grouse moors last year said that,there wasnrsquot a marked improvement in the populations of birds of prey on grouse moors , then a licensing system should be introduced. We await the Governmentrsquos response. This week Labour also called for the licensing of grouse shooting after a big increase in the illegal killing of birds during the lockdown.But in Scotland, Irsquom afraid, the signs of progress are not good. For a start, the Werritty report was based on the flawed premise that driven grouse shooting can be made acceptable. Werritty was explicitly looking for ways in which grouse moors could continue to be a part of the economy instead of questioning whether Scotlandrsquos countryside should tolerate a business that harms the countryside ndash through the burning of heather, for example.The reportrsquos conclusion on licensing also ended up being rather limp because the group that led the report was ided, which meant the compromise of suggesting a licensing systemthere is no improvement in bird of prey populations. Which gives the Scottish Government a get-out: wersquore waiting, theyrsquoll say, to seetherersquos been an improvement hellip still waiting hellip still waiting. The Government has also shown a lack of urgency in responding to Werritty. It does not look good.There are also serious question marks over whether licensing will work. First off, the people who are illegally killing birds of prey are unlikely to be deterred by a licensing systemtheyrsquore not deterred by the law as it stands Scotland for more than  years.Therersquos also a danger thatan ineffective licensing system will be introduced and then everything will just carry on as normal. I spoke to the conservationist Mark Avery about this recently and his view was that the whole idea of licensing depended on how robust the system was a weak one would pretty much allow the wildle criminals to carry on regardless.Some people in the shooting community feel theyrsquore being unfairly singled out over this. I remember speaking to one guy who runs a training school for gundogs who said he was frustrated that certain ways of killing animals ndash fishing for example ndash were seen as socially acceptable whereas shooting had a stigma attached to it. A farrier also told me that at least shooting enthusiasts are being honest about killing animals ndash townies on the other hand will happily tuck into burgers and fish and chips and yet judge people for shooting birds or deer.In some ways, I can see where the country sports enthusiasts are coming from on that one ndash for most of us, grouse shooting is a weird and distant practice and maybe that makes it easier to support moves to control it. But fishing doesnrsquot involve killing every other species in the water, whereas the ideal grouse moor from the point of view of landowners and gamekeepers is one thatrsquos devoid of any predator, which leads to predator control on a mass scale ndash legal and illegal.That is the key to the problem: a model that is effectively based on the killing of birds of prey. Perhaps licensing can do something to improve it. I hope so. Perhaps the Government will support licensing. I hope for that too. But it may be that it all rests on a simple question. Mark Thomas of the RSPB said this week that most of the bird of prey deaths theyrsquod seen during lockdown were linked in some way to shooting. So the question is: will licensing change the behaviour of those people  Or do we have to go further and ban driven grouse shooting completely Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. title: opinion-andy-maciver-national-renewal-covids-legacy-scotland
story: We should not be afraid to express that sentiment. We are in a war. Not a war against another nation, or a terrorist entity, but a war against a virus. And just as when we emerged from great wars, we took the opportunity to do things dferently, we must do the same now.The impact of coronavirus has been so severe, the consequences so profound, that we have an obligation on behalf of our people to exploit any silver lining we can possibly find in the enormous cloud which hovers above us.This can be a time of total national renewal. A time to hit the reset button across public le.I am no longer a party political player, and I have written in these pages on many occasions that I have found the SNP in government to be reliable and competent.Since its election in , a relatively small group of talented people have managed the country perfectly well, however the key word in this sentence is "managed". This has not been a radical government, and given the inevitability of its continuation until at least , we are all invested in that changing.In Nicola Sturgeon and John Swinney, the country has two people who, due to the formerrsquos historic popularity, are almost uniquely placed to take the country with them whatever they decide to do. Leaving aside the independence issue, to leave a legacy worth remembering, it is time to throw caution to the wind.The obvious first, and probably most important example, is uppermost in our thoughts this week: education. Our focus currently is on an acute issue in the form of the exam results, just as a few months ago it was on the acute question of when children wouldto school. But those are snapshots, stories, symptoms.:Jobs guarantee for young Scots backed by poundm fundingThe real issue here is not the acute but the chronic we have a state school system which is inadequately preparing our children for the world which greets them when they leave. I have now acquired direct experience of this, with four children in the state school system.It is not hyperbolic to say that I have encountered almost nothing which has genuinely impressed me. We are living a lie in this country, blindly accepting old tropes about Scotland having a world-leading education system. We do not. It is unambitious, with very little encouragement of the pursuit of excellence. It is secretive, with decisions iniably favouring councils and unions at the expense of pupils and parents, who are often treated as an inconvenience. And it is iniquitous, with thosewho have been able to pay for a house in a good catchment area effectively purchasing a chance for our children to emerge unscathed.Education leads to economic success. Education leads to high tax receipts. Education leads to good health and wellbeing. Education reduces welfare dependency. Education is everything. But we are sleepwalking into a national catastrophe because we are too afraid to admit that we are struggling.Today, the education secretary John Swinney faces a confidence vote a trap laid by opposition smelling political blood. Fine Irsquom certain the SNP would do the samethe shoe was on the other foot. But Irsquom not interested in that. As a citizen I recognise that the SNP will be in power for the next term of government and I believe that Mr Swinney has the skill, knowledge and respect to lead a rethink of everything. Starting age. Term times. Class sizes. Curriculum. Everything. We are all invested in his success.This is true not only of education. When the story of Covid  is told, Irsquod put the mortgage on the NHS emerging from that story as the hero. The NHS, as has often been said, is this countryrsquos national religion, and the hysteria which accompanies any sceptical comment about its quality ensures that the only political intervention it attracts is no-strings-attached increases in funding.:Letters: This is the final nail in the coffin of our education systemThat is no longer acceptable. As we try to analyse, in Scotland and the UK, whether we have coped well with Covid  relative to our peers, to leave the NHS out of that discussion would be an act of national self-harm.There are facts here, and they sit stubbornly in the way of the narrative. Our NHS has  percent fewer doctors per head than the OECD average. We have barely half the average number of hospital beds per head. We have less than half the number of MRI scanners, and one-third the number of CT scanners per head.We scrape into the OECD top- for survival rates for major cancers ndash colorectal, breast and cervical. We perform even worse ndash outside the top  ndash in mortality rates for heart attack, haemorrhagic stroke and ischemic stroke. And all of this is despite comparable financing of the system. Readers, we are not the envy of the world.This is not OK. We should stop thinking this is OK. We should stop saying this is OK. It demeans us to do so. You can support taxpayer-funded healthcare, as I do, and support the people who work in it, as I do , whilst also advocating a renewal of the delivery mechanism.However the critical first hurdle in a national renewal ndash the part we in Scotland have always found ourselves unable to leap ndash is to admit that we have problems. That we too often bask in our own mediocrity. So herersquos one idea. The Scottish Government should create a small National Renewal Unit. Give them a big travel budget. And let them bring back the best of the rest of the world to prepare us for a post-coronavirus future.bull Andy Maciver is Director of Message MattersOur columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: opinion-doug-marr-time-rethink-exam-system-ground
story: I donrsquot want to rain on the parade of the youngsters whose grades have been inflated, but colleges, universities and employers are always going to be sceptical about awards made in . I feel particularly sorry for this yearrsquos candidates who would have done well no matter which year they sat their exams, but whose  award will be forever tainted. Presumably next yearrsquos results will be back in line with previous years. If so, Higher pass rates in  will be around % lower than in , further undermining the credibility and value of this yearrsquos awards. Also, what about candidates in earlier years whose award was lower than their teachersrsquo estimates  I would like my physics award from  to be looked at again. If wersquore buying into the principle of teachersrsquo infallibility in estimating grades, there must be thousands out there with a legitimate cause for complaint. Oh, teachers are infallible for this year only, surely placing an even larger question mark over the  results. Additionally, has a precedent been created If, and itrsquos a big , this yearrsquos results mean anything at all, why have exams at all  The about-turn has been justied on the grounds that some pupils in lower performing schools have been disproportionately disadvantaged. That ignores the fact that these pupils, in these schools, are disadvantaged by the exam system every year. I worked in a school in a disadvantaged area where the staff went knocking on doors to get pupils to even turn up for their exams.Perhaps this years experience offers an opportunity to reconsider how we assess youngstersrsquo learning without sacricing the systemrsquos credibility.Predictably, the Education Secretaryrsquos political opponents have been quick to play to the gallery, but slower to say what they would have done. A Tory MSP even reinvented himself as a spokesman for ldquoour toughest communities. It will be interesting to hear his verdict on the very similar system of standardisation to be used in England.Politically, Mr Swinney may have taken the only option, but time will tellit was the correct decision for Scottish education and its exam system.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions.
